DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF EDUCATION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Annual appropriations to public schools, § 2-3. 
State Law reference- Board of education, Code of Ala., §§ 16-11-1, 16-11-2. 

Sec. 2-83. - Generally. 
(a)  A city board of education is hereby created and constituted, to be known and designated as the City Board of Education of Auburn, Alabama, to consist of five (5) members appointed by the governing body. Members shall be residents of the city and shall not be members of the governing body. Members of the board shall serve without compensation and shall be chosen solely because of their character and fitness, but no person shall be appointed or elected to the board who is in any way subject to the authority of the board. The board shall have all the duties, powers and authority provided by law for city boards of education. 
(b)  Annually at the regular meetings of the governing body in April the governing body shall elect a member of members of the board of education to succeed those whose term or terms of office expire that year. The terms of office of members of the city board of education shall be five (5) years, and the term of one member shall expire annually. In the event of a vacancy in the membership of the city board of education by resignation or otherwise, the fact shall be reported to the governing body by the said board, and the governing body shall elect a person to fill such vacancy for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1956, § 2-8) 
Secs. 2-84-2-94. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARK AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-95. - Created. 
    There is hereby created an advisory board to be named the Auburn Park and Recreation Advisory Board. 
(Ord. No. 431, § 1, 12-1-70) 
Sec. 2-96. - Members. 
(a)  The Auburn Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the governing body for terms of four (4) years. Each appointment shall run from the first day of the month following the appointment. In the event of a vacancy on the board or at the expiration of the term of office of any member of the board, the governing body shall appoint some resident citizen of the city to fill such unexpired or expiring term of office, as the case may be. All vacancies filled shall be filled for the expired term only and all other appointments shall be for a term of four (4) years. 
(b)  The board may make recommendations to the governing body regarding appointments at the time vacancies occur. Employees of the City of Auburn shall not be eligible for appointment to the board. The members of the board shall serve without pecuniary compensation. 
(Ord. No. 431, §§ II, III, 12-1-70; Ord. No. 1342, § 1, 12-19-89) 
Sec. 2-97. - Officers. 
    A chairman, vice-chairman, and a secretary shall be elected each year by a quorum of the Auburn Park and Recreation Advisory Board. 
(Ord. No. 431, § II, 12-1-70) 
Sec. 2-98. - Meetings. 
    The Auburn Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall meet monthly with the director of parks and recreation. Such meetings shall take place on regular specified day of each month as determined by a quorum of the board. Special meetings may be called by the director or the chairman of the board. 
(Ord. No. 431, § III, 12-1-70) 
Sec. 2-99. - Functions. 
    The Auburn Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall make recommendations to the director of parks and recreation, the city manager, the mayor and the governing body concerning the direction, supervision, and promotion of such recreation programs as will contribute to the general welfare of the residents of the city. The board shall make recommendations concerning utilization of all lands, buildings, equipment and other facilities assigned for recreational purposes to the park and recreation department by the governing body or purchased or leased by it from funds provided by the governing body. The board shall assist in cooperation with other local agencies and state and federal agencies for the purpose of acquiring, maintaining and improving recreational services and facilities for the city. The board is responsible for the development of bylaws which shall establish the organizational procedures for the park and recreation department. All action taken by the board shall be within the framework of this division. 
(Ord. No. 431, § IV, 12-1-70) 
Secs. 2-100-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TREE COMMISSION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1170, adopted Sept. 18, 1984, did not expressly amend the Code; therefore, codification as Div. 4 has been at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Municipal tree ordinance, § 17-61 et seq.; operation and duties of the tree commission, § 17-65. 

Sec. 2-111. - Created; members. 
    There is hereby established a tree commission consisting of seven (7) citizens of the city and appointed by the city council. Two (2) shall be appointed for one year; two (2) shall be appointed for two (2) years; one shall be appointed for three (3) years; one shall be appointed for four (4) years and one shall be appointed for five (5) years. Following the initial terms of office, the terms of the tree commissioners shall be three (3) years. In addition, two (2) members to the tree commission are hereby added, which members shall be citizens of the city, one of which shall serve an initial term of two (2) years and the other shall serve an initial term of three (3) years. Following the initial terms of office, the two (2) additional members shall serve terms as tree commissioners of three (3) years each. 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 1172, § 1, 11-6-84; Ord. No. 1377, § 1, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 1671, § 1, 11-19-96) 
Sec. 2-112. - Meetings. 
    The tree commission shall hold an initial meeting within thirty (30) days of its appointment and shall provide minutes for regular periodic meetings. The city manager shall assign a staff member to work with the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 2, 9-18-84) 
Sec. 2-113. - Functions. 
    The tree commission may make recommendations to the city council through the city manager relative to a tree planting program; may recommend the type and kind of trees to be planted on municipal streets, parks and other public places within the city. The commission may assist the city staff in providing information regarding the protection, maintenance, removal and planting of trees on public property; and may identify and recommend the removal of dead, dying, diseased or insect-infested trees. 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 3, 9-18-84) 
Cross reference- See also § 17-65, operation and duties of the tree commission. 
Sec. 2-114. - Division not to constitute restriction on certain maintenance, removal etc., of trees. 
(a)  Nothing contained in this division shall be construed to prevent public utilities from trimming and removing trees in connection with the construction and maintenance of the utility's facilities on public streets, alleys or rights-of-way; nothing contained in this division shall prevent the city from removing any tree or portion of any tree which the city deems to be dangerous not only from the tree's infected condition or danger of falling, but to be dangerous at corners or intersections in that the same would obscure the view of motor vehicles approaching said intersection. 
(b)  Nothing contained herein shall prevent the removal of any trees or portions of trees on private property, and this division is not intended to restrict the removal of trees by owners of private property. 
(Ord. No. 1170, §§ 4, 5, 9-18-84) 
DIVISION 5. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-115. - Established; membership. 
    There is hereby established an historic preservation commission consisting of seven (7) citizens who have demonstrated training or experience in the fields of history, architecture, architectural history, urban planning, archaeology, law, or, residents of an historic district or property once established by the city council. Not more than one-fifth of the members of the commission shall be public officials. 
(Ord. No. 1818, § 1(1), 3-2-99) 
Sec. 2-116. - Terms. 
    Except for the original members of the commission, members of the commission shall serve three-year terms and shall be appointed in such a manner so as to serve overlapping terms. Two (2) of the original members of the commission shall be appointed to serve one-year terms, two (2) of the original members of the commission shall be appointed to serve two-year terms, and the remaining three (3) original members of the commission shall be appointed to serve three-year terms. Members of the commission may be reappointed. 
(Ord. No. 1818, § 1(2), 3-2-99) 
Sec. 2-117. - Nomination; appointment. 
    Members of the commission shall be nominated by the mayor and appointed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1818, § 1(3), 3-2-99) 
Sec. 2-118. - Removal. 
    Members of the commission may be removed for cause by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1818, § 1(4), 3-2-99) 
Sec. 2-119. - Organization 
    Members of the commission shall elect a chairman and a vice chairman and such other officers as the members deem necessary. The commission shall hold an initial meeting within thirty (30) days of its appointment and shall provide minutes for regular meetings. The city manager shall assign a staff member to work with the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1818, § 1(5), 3-2-99) 
Sec. 2-120. - Duties; responsibilities; exception. 
    All other responsibilities and duties of this commission shall be followed in accordance with Sections 11-68-1 through 11-68-5 and 11-68-10 through 11-68-15 of the Code of the State of Alabama. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed as creating an architectural review board as set forth in [Code of Alabama,] Section 11-68-13. 
(Ord. No. 1818, § 1(6), (7), 3-2-99; Ord. No. 2302, § 1, 6-21-05) 
Sec. 2-120.1. - Procedures for recommendation and designation of historic districts and properties. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Certificate of appropriateness means a document evidencing approval by the Historic Preservation Commission of an application to make a material change in the appearance of a designated historic property or of a property located within a designated historic district. 
    Exterior architectural features means the architectural style, general design and general arrangement of the exterior of a building or other structure, including but not limited to the kind or texture of the building material and the type and style of all windows, doors, signs and other appurtenant architectural fixtures, features, details or elements relative to the foregoing. 
    Exterior environmental features means all those aspects of the landscape or the development of a site which affect the historical character of the property. 
    Historic district means a geographically definable area designated by the city council as a historic district. 
    Historic property means an individual building, structure, site, object or work of art including the adjacent area necessary for the proper appreciation thereof designated by the city council as a historic property. 
    Material change in appearance means a change that will effect either the exterior architectural or environmental features of a historic property or any building, structure, site, object, landscape feature or work of art within a historic district, such as: 
(1)  A reconstruction or alteration of the size, shape or facade of a historic property, including relocation of any doors or windows or removal or alteration of any architectural features, details or elements; 
(2)  Demolition or relocation of a historic structure; 
(3)  Commencement of excavation for construction purposes; 
(4)  A change in the location or advertising visible from the public right of way; or 
(5)  The erection, alteration, restoration or removal of any building or other structure within a historic property or district, including walls, fences, steps and pavements or other appurtenant features. 
(b)  Preliminary research by commission. 
(1)  Commission's mandate to conduct a survey of local historical resources. The Commission shall compile and collect information and conduct surveys of historic resources within the City of Auburn. 
(2)  Commission's power to recommend districts and buildings to the city council for designation. The commission shall present to the city council recommendations for historic districts and properties. 
(3)  Commission's documentation of proposed designation. Prior to the commission's recommendation of a historic district or historic property to the city council for designation, the commission shall prepare a report consisting of: 
a.  A physical description; 
b.  A statement of the historical, cultural, architectural and/or aesthetic significance; 
c.  A map showing district boundaries and classification (i.e. historic, non-historic) of individual properties therein, or showing boundaries of individual historic properties; 
d.  A statement justifying district or individual property boundaries; 
e.  Design standards for development in the historic district; and 
f.  Representative photographs. 
(c)  Designation of a historic district. 
(1)  Criteria for selection of historic districts. A historic district is a geographically definable area, which contains buildings, structures, sites, objects, landscape features and works of art or a combination thereof, which: 
a.  Represents one or more periods, styles or types of architecture typical of one or more eras in the history of the municipality, county, state or region; 
b.  Represents a significant aspect of the cultural, political, economic, military or social history of the locality, region, state or nation; 
c.  Has had a significant relationship with the life of a historic person or event, representing a major aspect of the history of the locality, region, state or nation; 
d.  Is a part of the historic, architectural, archaeological or aesthetic heritage of the locality, region, state or nation; 
e.  Contains vernacular structures which contribute to an overall character and sense of place which is representative of the City of Auburn. 
(2)  Boundaries of a historic district. Boundaries of a historic district shall be shown on an official map designated as a public record. 
(3)  Evaluation of properties with historic districts. Individual properties within historic districts shall be classified as: 
a.  Contributing (contributes to the district); 
b.  Non-contributing (does not contribute to the district). 
(c)  Designation of a historic property. 
(1)  Criteria for selection of historic properties. A historic property is a building, structure, site, object, work of art; including the adjacent area necessary for the proper appreciation or use thereof, deemed worthy of preservation by reason of value to the City of Auburn for one of the following reasons: 
a.  It is an outstanding example of a structure representative of its era; 
b.  It is one of the few remaining examples of past architectural style; 
c.  It is a place or structure associated with an event of persons of historic or cultural significance to the City of Auburn, State of Alabama of the region; 
d.  It is a site of natural or aesthetic interest that is continuing to contribute to the cultural or historical development and heritage of the municipality, county, state or region; or 
e.  The building or structure is an example of an architectural style, or combination of architectural styles, which is representative of the City of Auburn or which is unique to the City of Auburn. 
(2)  Boundary description. Boundaries shall be shown on an official map designated as a public record. 
(e)  Requirements for adopting an ordinance for the designation of historic districts and historic properties. 
(1)  Application for designation of historic districts or property. Designations may be proposed by the city council, the commission, or: 
a.  For historic districts - a historical society, neighborhood association or group of property owners may apply to the commission for designation; 
b.  For historic properties - a historical society, neighborhood association or property owner may apply to the commission for designation. 
(2)  Required components of a designation ordinance. Any ordinance designating any property or district as historic shall: 
a.  List each property in a proposed historic district or describe the proposed individual historic property; 
b.  Set forth the name(s) of the owner(s) of the designated property or properties; 
c.  Require that a certificate of appropriateness be obtained from the commission prior to any material change in appearance of the designated property; and 
d.  Require that the property or district be shown on an official map and be kept as a public record to provide notice of such designation. 
(3)  Required public hearings. The commission shall hold a public hearing on any proposed ordinance for the designation of any historic district or property. Notice of the hearing shall be published in at least three (3) consecutive issues in the principal newspaper of the local circulation, and written notice of the hearing shall be mailed by the commission to all owners and occupants of such properties. All such notices shall be published or mailed not less than ten (10) nor more than twenty (20) days prior to the date set for the public hearing. A notice sent via United States Mail to the last-known owner of the property shown on the Lee County tax roll and a notice sent via United States Mail to the address of the property to the attention of the occupant under this ordinance. 
(4)  Recommendations on proposed designations. A recommendation to affirm, modify or withdraw the proposed ordinance for designation shall be made by the commission within fifteen (15) days following the public hearing and shall be in the form of a resolution to the city council. 
(5)  City council action on commission recommendation. Following receipt of the commission's recommendation, the city council may adopt the ordinance as proposed, may adopt the ordinance with any amendments it deems necessary, or reject the ordinance. 
(6)  Notification of adoption of ordinance for designation. Within thirty (30) days following the adoption of the ordinance for designation by the city council, the owners and occupants of each designated historic property, and the owners and occupants of each designated historic property, and the owners and occupants of each structure, site or work of art located within a designated historic district, shall be given written notification of such designation by the city council which notice shall apprise said owners and occupants of the necessity of consulting the design review guidelines and obtaining a certificate of appropriateness prior to undertaking any material change in appearance of the historic property designated or within the historic district designated. A notice sent via the United States Mail to the last-known owner of the property shown on the Lee County tax roll and a notice sent via United States Mail to the address of the property to the attention of the occupant shall constitute legal notification to the owner and occupant under this ordinance. 
(7)  Notification of other agencies regarding designation. The commission shall notify all municipal agencies within the City of Auburn of the ordinance for designation. 
(Ord. No. 2302, § 2, 6-21-05) 
DIVISION 6. - GREENSPACE ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-121. - Establishment, appointment, and meetings. 
(1)  There is hereby established a greenspace advisory board consisting of seven (7) Auburn citizens. 
(2)  Members of the board shall serve four-year terms and shall be appointed initially in such a manner so as to serve overlapping terms. Two (2) of the original members of the board shall be appointed to serve one-year terms, two (2) of the original members of the board shall be appointed to serve two-year terms, two (2) of the original members of the board shall be appointed to serve three-year terms, one of the original members of the board shall be appointed to serve a four-year term. Members of the board may be reappointed for a second term. 
(3)  Members of the board shall be appointed by the city council. The board may make recommendations to the city council regarding appointments at the time vacancies occur. Employees of the City of Auburn shall not be eligible for appointment to the board. The members of the board shall serve without pecuniary compensation. 
(4)  Members of the board may be removed for cause by the city council. 
(5)  A chair, a vice chair, a secretary, and such other officers as the members deem necessary shall be elected each year by a quorum of the board. 
(6)  The board shall hold an initial meeting within thirty (30) days of its appointment and shall provide minutes for regular meetings. Such meetings shall take place on a schedule deemed necessary by a quorum of the board. Special meetings may be called by the city staff member(s) assigned by the city manager to work with the board or by the chair of the board after consultation with the city staff member(s) assigned to the board. 
(Ord. No. 2013, § 1, 7-3-01) 
Sec. 2-122. - Functions. 
(1)  The greenspace advisory board shall make recommendations concerning the acquisition of land and the development, implementation, and promotion of the greenspace program. 
(2)  The board shall make recommendations concerning utilization of all lands assigned for greenspace purposes by the governing body. 
(3)  The board shall work in cooperation with other local agencies and state and federal agencies for the purpose of acquiring, maintaining and improving greenspace services and facilities for the city. 
(4)  The board shall coordinate with the parks and recreation advisory board, the tree commission, and the bicycle committee to facilitate and enhance the coordination of common issues related to the greenspace program. 
(5)  The board shall recommend to the planning commission changes in and additions to the existing zoning ordinances and subdivision regulations that are necessary to meet the stated goals of the greenspace program. 
(6)  The board shall be an advocate for the greenspace program. This advocacy shall include developing an education and public awareness program to encourage public support for and participation in the greenspace program. In addition, the board shall work to foster communication and cooperation with Auburn University on greenspace issues. 
(7)  The board shall recommend to the city potential local, state, federal, and private funding sources. Based on the recommendation of the board, application may be made by the city to these sources for funds utilized for the development, implementation, and support of the greenspace program. 
(Ord. No. 2013, § 2, 7-3-01) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, adopted Jan. 8, 2008, repealed the former Ch. 3, §§ 3-1-3-55, and enacted a new Ch. 3 as set out herein. The former Ch. 3 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for full derivation. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    The words, terms and phrases used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them as defined in the Code of Ala., § 28-3-1, except the following term, which is defined in subsection (1) below. 
(1)  The word person shall mean a natural person, association, corporation, manager on duty, licensee or patron. Whenever used in a clause prescribing or imposing a fine or imprisonment or both, such term as applied to "association" shall mean the partners or members thereof and as applied to "corporation" shall mean the officers thereof, except as to private clubs, in which case the term "person" shall mean the individual who under the bylaws of such club shall have jurisdiction over the possession and sale of liquor therein. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. § 28-3-1(20). 
Sec. 3-2. - Interpretation. 
    This article shall be construed as an exercise by the city of the police power of the state, delegated to the city, in the regulation of purchase, sale, provision and consumption of alcoholic beverages within the jurisdiction of the city for the public welfare, health and peace of the people of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-3. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to the manufacturing, storage, wholesale and retail sales and purchases of alcoholic beverages as well as the provision, possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages within the City of Auburn. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-4. - Violating state statutes or rules. 
    Any person who violates any provision or any regulation promulgated by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board relating to the sale of liquor, fortified wine, table wine, beer, malt or brewed beverages or any provision of law contained in the Code of the City of Auburn or Code of Ala., § 28-3-1, et seq., or who engages in the sale or purchase for resale of alcoholic beverages without first obtaining a City of Auburn alcoholic beverage license shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00) and thirty (30) days in jail or as provided in section 1-9 of the City Code, and the license of any such person shall, upon conviction, be subject to revocation by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Cross reference- State offenses adopted, § 13-1. 
Sec. 3-5. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00) and thirty (30) days in jail or as provided in section 1-9 of the City Code, and the license of any such person, upon conviction, shall be subject to revocation by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-5.1. - Penalty for multiple convictions. 
(a)  In the event that an alcoholic beverage licensee or a person who is required by the provisions of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board Administrative Code, this chapter of the City Code or the Code of Ala., § 28-3-1, et seq., to obtain an alcoholic beverage license is convicted of three (3) violations of this chapter or the State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board Administrative Code within a five-year period, the city council of the City of Auburn shall hold a hearing to consider revocation of any business and/or alcoholic beverage licenses applicable to the licensed premises upon which the violations occurred. 
(b)  In the event that a person, employed by either an alcoholic beverage licensee or employed by a person who is required by the provisions of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board Administrative Code, this chapter of the City Code or the Code of Ala., § 28-3-1, to obtain an alcoholic beverage license, is convicted of three (3) violations of this chapter or the regulations promulgated by the State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board within a five-year period, the city council of the City of Auburn shall hold a hearing to consider revocation of any business and/or alcoholic beverage license applicable to the licensed premises upon which the violations occurred. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall preclude the city council from revoking the license of a licensee upon conviction of any single violation or misdemeanor or as otherwise prescribed in this Code, the Code of Alabama or the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board Administrative Code should the council so choose. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-6. - Fees and taxes, generally. 
    Any fee or tax not specifically referenced in this chapter shall be set, levied and calculated according to the provisions of article VI herein. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Secs. 3-7-3-9. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING 

Sec. 3-10. - Generally. 
    The application process for and the granting of city licenses for persons to purchase at wholesale or to sell alcoholic beverages within the city limits shall be in compliance with the Code of Ala., § 28-3-1. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-11. - License required. 
    No person shall sell any alcoholic beverages, whether at wholesale or at retail, whether on-premises or off-premises, within the city limits of the City of Auburn without possession of both a current State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board license and a City of Auburn alcoholic beverage license, both of which are in good standing, that is, there are no taxes or license fees associated with such licenses that are past due. No person shall purchase any alcoholic beverages at wholesale within the City of Auburn except from a wholesaler or distributor which has been duly licensed by the State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board and the City of Auburn, if required. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-12. - Grant of license, to whom. 
    City alcoholic beverage licenses shall be granted and issued by the city only to reputable individuals or to associations whose members are reputable individuals or to reputable corporations organized under the laws of the State of Alabama or duly qualified thereunder to do business in the State of Alabama, and then only when it appears to the city that all officers and directors of the corporation are reputable individuals. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-13. - License application procedure, due date and delinquent date. 
(a)  No person shall sell alcoholic beverages within the City of Auburn without first obtaining a city business license and a city alcoholic beverage license. City alcoholic beverage licenses shall expire on December 31 of each calendar year. 
(b)  Any person desiring to sell alcoholic beverages, whether at wholesale or retail, within the City of Auburn, shall first apply to the State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control (ABC) Board for a license to sell alcoholic beverages. Following application to the State ABC Board, the applicant shall notify the City of Auburn that an application to the state has been submitted. Following review by the City of Auburn, the state application shall be submitted to the city council of the City of Auburn for their consideration. Following consideration by the city council, the City of Auburn shall notify the State ABC Board and the applicant of the city council's approval or denial. 
(c)  The City of Auburn shall not issue a city alcoholic beverage license to any person who does not possess a current State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board license and a current City of Auburn business license. A City of Auburn business license shall not be considered "current" if there are any unpaid license fees, taxes, penalties or interest accrued in relation to the said business license; further provided that the City of Auburn shall not issue a city alcoholic beverage license until payment of the full amount of the alcoholic beverage license fee and business license fee then due have been paid. 
(d)  The City of Auburn shall not accept an alcoholic beverage license application from any applicant for whom a city alcoholic beverage license has been denied within one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the submission of the application. 
(e)  Following the issuance of a person's initial city alcoholic beverage license, each person shall obtain a renewal of the city alcoholic beverage license for each subsequent calendar year in which the person is subject to the provisions of this chapter. Renewals of alcoholic beverage licenses shall be due on January 2 of each calendar year and shall be considered delinquent if not renewed on or before February 15 of each calendar year. Renewals of alcoholic beverage licenses shall not be issued until the person's City of Auburn business license has been renewed for the same calendar year. 
(f)  No person shall sell alcoholic beverages within the police jurisdiction of the City of Auburn without first obtaining a license to sell such from the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. Any person desiring to sell alcoholic beverages, whether at wholesale or retail, within the police jurisdiction of the City of Auburn, shall first apply to the State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control (ABC) Board for a license to sell alcoholic beverages. Following application to the State ABC Board, the applicant shall notify the City of Auburn that an application to the state has been submitted. Following review by the City of Auburn, the state application shall be submitted to the city council of the City of Auburn for their consideration. Following consideration by the city council, the City of Auburn shall notify the State ABC Board and the applicant of the city council's approval, denial or no position. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-14. - Compliance with City of Auburn zoning ordinance. 
    The City of Auburn shall not issue a city alcoholic beverage license to any applicant unless the alcoholic beverage license requested to be issued has been reviewed by the city and determined that such license will be in compliance with the City of Auburn zoning ordinance in effect at the time of the application for the city alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-15. - License categories. 
    Alcoholic beverage licenses granted by the City of Auburn shall be issued for the same categories as the alcoholic beverage license categories promulgated by the State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-16. - License fees. 
    In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, any person prior to the sale of any alcoholic beverages within the city and prior to the issuance of an alcoholic beverage license by the city for such purpose shall pay to the city an annual alcoholic beverage license fee. Alcoholic beverage license fees for city alcoholic beverage licenses are hereby fixed and levied and shall be in the amounts as stated in article VI of this chapter of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-17. - Late fee for failure to obtain license or pay license fees when due. 
    In the event that any alcoholic beverage licensee required by this chapter to obtain an alcoholic beverage license has not applied for such license and the license fee therefor has not been paid until after February 15 of the calendar year in which the alcoholic beverage license fee is due, a late penalty shall be assessed as provided for in article VI of this chapter of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-18. - Records and reports required. 
(a)  Each person licensed or required to be licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall keep accurate records of all purchases and all sales of all alcoholic beverages made by such person. Such records shall be sufficiently detailed to evidence compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Each person subject to the city liquor tax, as levied by section 3-31 of this chapter, shall file a monthly liquor tax return as provided by section 3-32 of this chapter. 
(c)  Such records and reports required by the provisions of this chapter and all documents supporting the records and reports (including books of account, invoices of purchases and sales receipts, correspondence from the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, bank statements, memoranda, etc.) shall be preserved for a period of not less than three (3) years subsequent to the year in which the transactions recorded by records, reports and documents occurred and shall be open to inspection and audit, during regular business hours, by the city manager or his authorized representative within ten (10) city business days (i.e., days on which the city is open for business) following the written request of the city. If the licensee or person required to be licensed under the provisions of this article does not furnish the requested records, reports and documents within ten (10) city business days, the city manager shall set a hearing before the city council and shall notify such licensee or person, in writing, of the hearing so established. If the licensee fails to appear at the hearing or, having appeared, does not furnish proof to the city council of his compliance with this article, the city council shall revoke the alcoholic beverage license issued under authority of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-19. - Transfer or assignment of license. 
(a)  No city alcoholic beverage license may be transferred or assigned by the licensee without the consent of the city council. The city may authorize the transfer of any license from one business location to another business location, upon proper application being made to the city council, provided that the second business is under the same ownership as the original business; but no such transfer shall be made for the transaction of business at the second location if such location constitutes a location for which the alcoholic beverage license cannot be lawfully issued. 
(b)  In the event that fifty-one (51) per cent of the ownership of a corporate or partnership licensee is sold or transferred to a person or entity not previously an owner of the business-licensee during the license year, such sale or transfer shall be deemed to terminate the alcoholic beverage license issued under this division and shall require a new license to be applied for in order for the business to continue selling alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  Every applicant for the transfer of the location of a business having a current city alcoholic beverage license shall file a written application with the city. Such application for transfer shall be reviewed by the city manager and submitted to the city council for its consideration for approval or denial. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Secs. 3-20-3-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIQUOR TAX 

Sec. 3-30. - License categories subject to liquor tax. 
    The alcoholic beverage license categories which shall be subject to the city liquor tax shall be as stated in article VI of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-31. - Amount of levy and transactions subject to levy. 
    In addition to all other taxes and license fees now imposed by law, every person selling liquor (including fortified wine) at retail within the city shall pay to the City of Auburn a liquor tax, for which the amount is hereby fixed and levied as provided in article VI of this chapter 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-32. - Procedure for remitting liquor tax, due date and delinquent date. 
    The City of Auburn shall invoice the city liquor tax each month for all liquor purchases (including fortified wine) made in the preceding month based on the monthly Wholesale Liquor and Wine Report received from the State of Alabama Alcohol Beverage Control Board. The licensee will use the provided invoice to pay the monthly tax on or before the prescribed date on each invoice. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08; Ord. No. 2807, § 1, 1-22-13) 
Sec. 3-33. - Late fee for failure to remit liquor tax when due. 
    If the liquor tax specified herein to be paid monthly is not paid on or before the prescribed date of each invoice, a late fee, as specified in article VI, shall be added to the amount then due; and if any licensee subject to such liquor tax shall fail to make any payment herein provided for prior to the last business day of the month in which such payment shall become due, then the city council of the City of Auburn may hold a hearing to consider the revocation of the licensee's city alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08; Ord. No. 2807, § 2, 1-22-13) 
Sec. 3-34. - Records and reports required. 
    Each person licensed under the provisions of this article shall keep accurate records of all purchases of liquor (including fortified wine) made by such person; and shall file a statement, verified by the oath of the person or an authorized officer or agent thereof, by the twentieth day of each month showing the amount of purchases of liquor (including fortified wine) for the preceding month. Such monthly liquor purchases reports shall be filed with the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Secs. 3-35-3-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WHOLESALE TABLE WINE TAX 

Sec. 3-40. - Amount of levy and transactions subject to levy. 
    In addition to all other license fees and taxes imposed by law, there is hereby fixed and levied a privilege or excise tax on the volume of table wine sold by wholesalers within the City of Auburn. The amount of such wholesale table wine tax shall be as specified in article VI of this chapter. This wholesale table wine tax shall be added to the sales price of all table wine sold at wholesale and shall be collected by the wholesaler from each purchaser. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-41. - Procedure for remitting wholesale table wine tax, due date. 
    Wholesalers making sales of table wine within the city shall remit to the city the wholesale table wine tax hereby levied. Each such wholesaler shall file a statement each month with the city manager or his designated representative, showing the number of liters of table wine sold during the preceding month to retailers whose businesses are located within the city limits of the City of Auburn and calculating the amount of the wholesale table wine tax thereon; further provided that the taxes due according to each such wholesale table wine tax return shall be remitted to the city with the tax return. Wholesale table wine tax returns and remittances shall be due no later than the fifteenth day of each month for wholesale table wine taxes collected during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-42. - Late fee for failure to remit wholesale table wine tax when due. 
    If the wholesale table wine tax specified herein to be paid monthly is not paid on or before the twentieth day of each month, a late fee, as specified in article VI, shall be added to the amount then due; and if any licensee subject to such wholesale table wine tax shall fail to make any payment herein provided for prior to the last business day of the month in which such payment shall become due, then the city council of the City of Auburn may hold a hearing to consider the revocation of the licensee's city alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-43. - Records and reports required. 
    Each person licensed under the provisions of this chapter to sell table wine at wholesale shall keep accurate records of all purchases and sales of table wine made by such person; and shall file a statement, verified by the oath of the licensee or an authorized officer or agent thereof, by the twentieth day of each month showing the amount of sales of table wine for the preceding month. Such monthly wholesale table wine purchases reports shall be filed with the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-44. - Transactions exempt from wholesale table wine tax. 
    The wholesale table wine tax levied by the article shall not be imposed on the sale, trade, or barter of table wine by one licensed wholesaler to another wholesaler licensed to sell table wine at wholesale in this state, which such transactions are hereby made exempt from said wholesale table wine tax. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Secs. 3-45-3-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE OPERATIONS WITHIN THE CITY 

Sec. 3-50. - Purchase from unauthorized or unlicensed persons; sale of alcoholic beverages on which applicable taxes have not been paid. 
    No licensee shall sell any alcoholic beverages in the city except where such alcoholic beverages have been purchased from a wholesaler or distributor duly licensed by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board and by the city, if required, and no licensee shall sell any alcoholic beverages unless all applicable state and local taxes have been paid on such alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-51. - Sales, etc. after hours for persons licensed for on-premises sales. 
(a)  The provisions of this section shall apply to the retail sale of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption and to the retail sale of alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption by on-premises licensees but shall not apply to those businesses engaged solely in the retail sale of such alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption nor to the wholesale of alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, furnish or give away any alcoholic beverages in premises licensed for on-premises sales of alcoholic beverages during the hours as specified below: 
(1)  Sundays: 2:01 a.m. through 12:00 p.m. (noon); 
(2)  Mondays through Saturdays: 2:31 a.m. through 8:30 a.m. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or fail to prevent the possession or consumption of any alcoholic beverages in premises licensed for on-premises sales of alcoholic beverages during the hours as specified below: 
(1)  Sundays: 2:01 a.m. through 12:00 p.m. (noon); 
(2)  Mondays through Saturdays: 2:31 a.m. through 8:30 a.m. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase or obtain any alcoholic beverages in premises licensed for on-premises sales of alcoholic beverages during the hours specified in subsection 3-51(b) above. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverages in premises licensed for on-premises sales of alcoholic beverages during the hours specified in subsection 3-51(c) above. 
(f)  This section (3-51) shall not apply to any current Class I or Class II club liquor license that was issued by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board pursuant to state law prior to the effective date of Ordinance No. 2530-A. Any new Class I or Class II club liquor license issued after the effective date of Ordinance No. 2530-A shall comply with the provisions of this section (3-51). Any current Class I or Class II club liquor license that is transferred after the effective date of Ordinance No. 2530-A shall comply with the provisions of this section (3-51). 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08; Ord. No. 2656, § 1, 4-20-10) 
Sec. 3-52. - Sales, etc. after hours for persons licensed for off-premises sales. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, furnish or give away any alcoholic beverages or to allow or fail to prevent the possession of any alcoholic beverages in premises licensed for off-premises sales of alcoholic beverages during the hours as specified below: 
Sundays: 2:01 a.m. through 12:00 p.m. (noon). 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to consume or to allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverages in premises licensed for off-premises only sales of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-53. - Sales, etc., to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, furnish or give away alcoholic beverages to a minor or to attempt to sell, furnish or give away alcoholic beverages to a minor. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-54. - Purchases, etc., by minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase, obtain, possess or consume alcoholic beverages within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-55. - Access to licensed premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or holder of a City of Auburn alcoholic beverage license to prohibit access or entry by any law enforcement or codes enforcement officer at any time while any person is present within the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-56. - Drink specials, discounted prices, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or holder of a City of Auburn alcoholic beverage license to offer drink specials or discounted prices for alcoholic beverages such that the drink special price or discounted price for such alcoholic beverage is less than one-half (1/2) of the usual, customary, established retail price charged by such person for such alcoholic beverage; provided further that such person may not charge less than one dollar ($1.00) for a standard-sized alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. No. 2530-A, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-57. - Public possession or consumption of alcohol. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (c) below and in section 3-58, no person shall possess or drink malt, vinous, spirituous or other intoxicating liquors within the confines or parking area of any stadium, basketball court or other places in the city in which athletic events are in progress or during or near to the playing of public school or other athletic contests or events; and no person shall drink any such liquors in any other public place except in places where such liquors are sold at retail for consumption on the premises pursuant to a license issued by the city and the Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, a "public place" shall be defined and shall be held as including the following: 
(1)  Any street, alley, sidewalk, public park, public building, such as but not limited to the city hall, library, school building, auditorium, recreation center and any other public building open to the public; 
(2)  Any theater, show, movie house, skating rink, dance hall or other place of amusement; 
(3)  Any parking lot of any public building, apartment house, theater, movie house, skating rink, dance hall or other place of amusement, restaurant, store or other place where merchandise of any kind is offered for sale; 
(4)  Any restaurant, dining room, lobby or other public or quasi-public room of a hotel or other similar place; 
(5)  Any store or place where merchandise of any kind is offered for sale; 
(6)  Any other place not included in the foregoing which is generally accessible to the public, such as but not limited to common areas of apartment houses; however, such place shall not include a private residence and its surrounding premises. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, alcoholic beverages may be served and consumed: 
(1)  In outdoor cafes approved in accordance with the provisions of article XII of chapter 12 of the Code of the City of Auburn provided the adjacent host eating establishment holds both a valid State of Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board license and a City of Auburn alcoholic beverage license and a valid city business license. 
(2)  During special community events as may be specifically approved for individual events upon application to the city council provided the required city and state alcoholic beverage licenses are obtained. 
(3)  During public or private events in public buildings and facilities as may be specifically approved for individual events upon application to the city manager or his designee provided the required city and state alcoholic beverage licenses are obtained. 
(d)  The applicant for a special community event per subsection 3-57(c)(2) or for a public or private event per section 3-57(c)(3) shall arrange with the city public safety department to review the need for security services for the event. The cost of any such security services shall be paid by the applicant unless otherwise approved. The public safety department shall detail the number of security officers deemed appropriate to maintain public safety at the event based on factors including but not limited to the type of event, number of attendees, and event venue. 
(e)  The applicant for a special community event per subsection 3-57(c)(2) or for a public or private event per subsection 3-57(c)(3) shall file with the city manager a statement agreeing to indemnify and hold harmless the city, its officials, representatives, agents, servants, and employees from any and all claims, damages, judgments, cost, or expenses, including attorney's fees, which they may incur or be required to pay because of any bodily injury, including death, or property damage suffered by any person as a result of or related in any way to the event on city property that involves the furnishing, serving, or sale of alcohol. 
(f)  The applicant for a special community event per subsection 3-57(c)(2) or for a public or private event per subsection 3-57(c)(3) shall file with the city manager a certificate of insurance showing that the person carries comprehensive general liability insurance or event insurance and liquor liability insurance (if required) issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state. Limits of liability for general liability insurance or event insurance shall be at a minimum, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) personal and advertising injury, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) general aggregate and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) products/completed operations aggregate. The general liability insurance or event insurance will provide coverage for the serving or furnishing of alcoholic beverages. If the event involves the sale of alcoholic beverages or is catered by a person in the business of selling, serving or furnishing alcoholic beverages, a certificate of liquor liability insurance will be required. Limits of liability for liquor liability shall be at a minimum, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) aggregate. The city will be named as an additional insured under the general liability insurance, event insurance and liquor liability insurance (if required). The certificate of insurance shall provide the city with thirty (30) days written notice of cancellation or material change in the general liability insurance, event insurance, and liquor liability insurance (if required). The cancellation of any such coverage shall have the effect of suspending the permit for the event(s) covered thereby until a new certificate of insurance complying with the provisions of this section is filed with the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2656, § 2, 4-20-10; Ord. No. 2774, § 1, 8-7-12; Ord. No. 2966, § 1, 3-1-16) 
Sec. 3-58. - Entertainment districts. 
(a)  An entertainment district as provided by Act No. 2012-438 of the Legislature of the State of Alabama is hereby established for the portion of downtown Auburn bounded by: 
The centerline of Glenn Avenue between Wright Street and Gay Street; 
The centerline of Gay Street between Glenn Avenue and Thach Avenue; 
The northern right-of-way line of Thach Avenue between Gay Street and College Street; 
The western right-of-way line of College Street between Thach Avenue and Magnolia Avenue; 
The southern right-of-way line of Magnolia Avenue between College Street and Wright Street; 
The centerline of Wright Street between Magnolia Avenue and Glenn Avenue, 
(b)  Within the entertainment district as herein defined, the Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board may issue an entertainment district designation for any on-premises retail alcohol license which allows the licensee to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the licensed premises. 
(c)  The city council may designate special community events in all or part of the entertainment district allowing patrons of establishments with an on-premises retail alcohol license having the entertainment district designation to exit the licensed premises with open containers of alcoholic beverages and consume alcoholic beverages anywhere within the confines of the entertainment district. 
(d)  Public possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages in the entertainment district shall be subject to the rules established in this subsection and will be permitted only during the specified hours established for the special community events designated by the city council. 
(1)  Patrons shall not be permitted to enter a licensed premises with open or closed containers of alcoholic beverages acquired elsewhere. 
(2)  Patrons shall not be permitted to possess or consume alcoholic beverages within the confines of the entertainment district as herein defined that are acquired outside the confines of the entertainment districts. 
(3)  Patrons may not exit licensed premises with open glass containers of alcoholic beverages. All alcoholic beverages sold for consumption outside the licensed premises shall be contained in an original aluminum container or other shatter resistant container such as a plastic cup. 
(e)  A licensee who receives an entertainment district designation shall comply with all laws, rules, and regulations which govern its license type except as specifically provided in this section. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to allow the sale and consumption of alcohol in the entertainment district beyond the hours established in sections 3-51 and 3-52 or the sale of alcohol to minors as specified in section 3-54. 
(Ord. No. 2774, § 2, 8-7-12) 
Secs. 3-59-3-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES LICENSE FEES AND TAXES

    The City of Auburn shall levy alcoholic beverage license fees, as provided for in section 3-16 of this chapter; these alcoholic beverage license fees shall be as follows:
