(1)  Where city, county, and/or state sales taxes total six per cent (6% bracket): 
On sales of $0.01 to and including $0.08 tax to be collected none 
On sales of $0.09 to and including $0.24 tax to be collected $0.01 
On sales of $0.25 to and including $0.41 tax to be collected $0.02 
On sales of $0.42 to and including $0.58 tax to be collected $0.03 
On sales of $0.59 to and including $0.74 tax to be collected $0.04 
On sales of $0.75 to and including $0.91 tax to be collected $0.05 
On sales of $0.92 to and including $1.08 tax to be collected $0.06 
(2)  Where city, county, and/or state sales taxes total six and one-half per cent (61/2% bracket): 
On sales of $0.01 to and including $0.07 tax to be collected none 
On sales of $0.08 to and including $0.23 tax to be collected $0.01 
On sales of $0.24 to and including $0.38 tax to be collected $0.02 
On sales of $0.39 to and including $0.53 tax to be collected $0.03 
On sales of $0.54 to and including $0.70 tax to be collected $0.04 
On sales of $0.71 to and including $0.84 tax to be collected $0.05 
On sales of $0.85 to and including $0.99 tax to be collected $0.06 
On sales of $1.00 to and including $1.15 tax to be collected $0.07 
(3)  Where city, county, and/or state sales taxes total seven per cent (7% bracket): 
On sales of $0.01 to and including $0.07 tax to be collected none 
On sales of $0.08 to and including $0.21 tax to be collected $0.01 
On sales of $0.22 to and including $0.35 tax to be collected $0.02 
On sales of $0.36 to and including $0.49 tax to be collected $0.03 
On sales of $0.50 to and including $0.64 tax to be collected $0.04 
On sales of $0.65 to and including $0.78 tax to be collected $0.05 
On sales of $0.79 to and including $0.92 tax to be collected $0.06 
On sales of $0.93 to and including $1.07 tax to be collected $0.07 
(4)  Where city, county, and/or state sales taxes total seven and one-half per cent (71/2% bracket): 
On sales of $0.01 to and including $0.06 tax to be collected none 
On sales of $0.07 to and including $0.20 tax to be collected $0.01 
On sales of $0.21 to and including $0.33 tax to be collected $0.02 
On sales of $0.34 to and including $0.46 tax to be collected $0.03 
On sales of $0.47 to and including $0.59 tax to be collected $0.04 
On sales of $0.60 to and including $0.73 tax to be collected $0.05 
On sales of $0.74 to and including $0.86 tax to be collected $0.06 
On sales of $0.87 to and including $0.99 tax to be collected $0.07 
On sales of $1.00 to and including $1.13 tax to be collected $0.08 
(5)  Where city, county, and/or state sales taxes total eight per cent (8% bracket): 
On sales of $0.01 to and including $0.06 tax to be collected none 
On sales of $0.07 to and including $0.18 tax to be collected $0.01 
On sales of $0.19 to and including $0.31 tax to be collected $0.02 
On sales of $0.32 to and including $0.43 tax to be collected $0.03 
On sales of $0.44 to and including $0.56 tax to be collected $0.04 
On sales of $0.57 to and including $0.68 tax to be collected $0.05 
On sales of $0.69 to and including $0.81 tax to be collected $0.06 
On sales of $0.82 to and including $0.93 tax to be collected $0.07 
On sales of $0.94 to and including $1.06 tax to be collected $0.08 
(6)  Where city, county, and/or state sales taxes total eight and one-half per cent (81/2% bracket): 
On sales of $0.01 to and including $0.05 tax to be collected none 
On sales of $0.06 to and including $0.17 tax to be collected $0.01 
On sales of $0.18 to and including $0.29 tax to be collected $0.02 
On sales of $0.30 to and including $0.41 tax to be collected $0.03 
On sales of $0.42 to and including $0.52 tax to be collected $0.04 
On sales of $0.53 to and including $0.64 tax to be collected $0.05 
On sales of $0.65 to and including $0.76 tax to be collected $0.06 
On sales of $0.77 to and including $0.88 tax to be collected $0.07 
On sales of $0.89 to and including $0.99 tax to be collected $0.08 
On sales of $1.00 to and including $1.11 tax to be collected $0.09 
(7)  Where city, county, and/or state sales taxes total nine per cent (9% bracket): 
On sales of $0.01 to and including $0.05 tax to be collected none 
On sales of $0.06 to and including $0.16 tax to be collected $0.01 
On sales of $0.17 to and including $0.28 tax to be collected $0.02 
On sales of $0.29 to and including $0.38 tax to be collected $0.03 
On sales of $0.39 to and including $0.49 tax to be collected $0.04 
On sales of $0.50 to and including $0.61 tax to be collected $0.05 
On sales of $0.62 to and including $0.71 tax to be collected $0.06 
On sales of $0.72 to and including $0.83 tax to be collected $0.07 
On sales of $0.84 to and including $0.94 tax to be collected $0.08 
On sales of $0.95 to and including $1.05 tax to be collected $0.09 
(8)  Where city, county, and/or state sales taxes total less than a nine (9) per cent, there shall be added to the sales price and collected from the purchaser an amount equal to the total prescribed percentage of such sales price. 
(9)  Noninterference with state and/or county sales tax statutes. Nothing in this section shall be construed to interfere with the collections and payment of state and/or county sales taxes levied by statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 5, 12-7-91; Ord. No. 2709, § 1, 6-21-11) 
Sec. 12-86. - Disposition of revenue from taxes. 
    All monies received from taxes levied by this article shall be deposited into the general fund of the city (for appropriation to general operating expenses of the city government) and may be pledged to secure any debt of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 6, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-87. - Taxes due monthly; filing of reports. 
    The taxes levied under the provisions of this article, except as otherwise provided, shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the tax accrues. 
(1)  On or before the twentieth of each month, every person on whom the sales taxes levied by this article are imposed shall render to the city, on a form prescribed by the city, a true and correct statement showing the gross sales, the gross proceeds of sales or gross receipts of the business, as the case may be, for the next preceding month; the amount of gross proceeds or gross receipts which are not subject to the tax, or are not to be used as a measurement of the taxes due by such person, and the nature thereof; together with such other information as the city may demand and require. 
(2)  On or before the twentieth of each month, every person on whom the use taxes levied by this article are imposed shall render to the city, on a form prescribed by the city, a true and correct statement showing the total sales price of the tangible personal property sold by such seller, the storage, use or consumption of which became subject to the tax imposed by this article during the preceding month and such other information as the city may deem necessary for the proper administration of this article. 
(3)  At the time of making such monthly report such person shall compute the taxes due and shall pay to the city the amount of taxes shown to be due. When the total tax for which any person liable under this article does not exceed ten dollars ($10.00) for any month, a quarterly return and remittance in lieu of the monthly returns may be made on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the end of the quarter for which the tax is due when specifically authorized by the city in response to the taxpayer's request and under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the city. The city, for good cause, may extend the time for making any return required under the provisions of this division, but the time for filing any such return shall not be extended for a period greater than sixty (60) days from the date such return is due to be made. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 7, 12-7-91; Ord. No. 1626, § 1, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 2118, § 1, 5-6-03) 
Sec. 12-88. - Records to be kept. 
    It shall be the duty of every person engaging or continuing in this state in any business for which a privilege tax is imposed in this article, to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross sales, gross proceeds of sales, gross receipts or gross receipts of sales of such business, the total sales price of the tangible personal property sold by such business, the storage, use or consumption of which became subject to the tax imposed by this article during the preceding month and such other books and other accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax for which he is liable, under the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of every person to keep and preserve, for a period of three (3) years, all invoices of goods, wares and merchandise purchased, for resale and otherwise, and all such books, invoices and other records shall be open for examination at any time, by the city or its duly authorized agent. Any person selling both at wholesale and retail shall keep his books so as to show separately the gross proceeds of wholesale sales and the gross proceeds of retail sales. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 8, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-89. - Penalty for failure to make reports or keep records. 
    Any person subject to the provisions of this article who shall fail to make the reports or any of them, as herein required, or who shall fail to keep the records as herein required shall upon conviction be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each month of such failure shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 9, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-90. - Penalty for willful refusal to make reports or permit examination of records. 
    Any person subject to the provisions of this article willfully refusing to make the reports herein required, or who shall refuse to permit the examination of his records by the city, or its duly authorized agents, shall upon conviction be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and in addition may be imprisoned 
in the city jail for a period not to exceed six (6) months. Each month of failure to make such reports shall constitute a separate offense, and each refusal of a written demand of the city to examine, inspect, or audit such records shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 10, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-91. - Penalty for failure to pay tax; interest. 
    Any person who fails to pay the tax herein levied within the time required by this article shall pay, in addition to the tax, a penalty of ten (10) per cent of the amount of tax due, together with interest thereon at the rate of one-half of one per cent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date at which the tax herein levied became due and payable, such penalty and interest to be assessed and collected as a part of the tax. The city, if a good and sufficient reason is shown, may waive or remit the penalty of ten (10) per cent or a portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 11, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-92. - Notice to taxpayer and assessment of tax upon failure to make return. 
    If any taxpayer fails to make the returns herein required, the city shall issue written notice, by certified or registered mail, or written notice delivered by its authorized agent, to such taxpayer to make such returns forthwith, and if such taxpayer fails or refuses to make such return, or returns, within thirty (30) days from the date of such notice, then the city shall make return for such delinquent taxpayer upon such information as it may reasonably obtain, and shall assess the taxes due thereon, and shall add a penalty for failure to make such return and payment of twenty-five (25) per cent of the tax due, as assessed by the city, and interest at the rate of one-half of one per cent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date such taxes were due. The city, if a good and sufficient reason is shown for such delinquency, may waive or remit the twenty-five (25) per cent penalty, or a portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 12, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-93. - Tax a lien on property. 
    The tax, together with interest and penalties imposed by this article, shall be a lien upon the property of any person subject to the provisions of this article, and the provisions of the revenue laws of the State of Alabama applying to liens for license taxes shall apply fully to the taxes herein levied. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 13, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-94. - Execution, levy and sale for taxes. 
    If any final assessment of taxes herein levied is not paid within thirty (30) days after such assessment becomes final if no appeal has been taken, in cases where appeal is authorized, the city shall issue an execution therefor directed to any sheriff of the State of Alabama commanding him to levy upon and sell the real and personal property of the person against whom such execution is directed, found in his county, together with all penalties assessed. The sheriff shall, within five (5) days after the receipt thereof, file with the clerk of the circuit court of his county a copy thereof, and thereupon the circuit clerk shall enter in the judgment roll, in the column of judgment debtors, the name of the taxpayer named in the execution, the amount of the tax and damages and penalties for which the execution is issued and the day when such copy is filed; thereupon, the amount of such execution so docketed shall become a lien upon the real and personal property of the person against whom it is issued in the same manner as judgments duly enrolled from the circuit court or court of like jurisdiction. 
    The sheriff thereupon shall levy upon any property of the taxpayer with like effect and in the manner prescribed by law in respect to execution issued upon judgments of the circuit court or court of like jurisdiction, and the remedies of attachment and garnishment shall apply fully to such execution, and the officer shall be entitled to the same fees for his services as now allowed by law for like services to be collected in the same manner as now provided by law for like services. The sheriff shall make due return of such execution within sixty (60) days of the issuance thereof to the department and upon such return alias or in pluries executions may be issued by the city which shall be executed in the same manner. Such lien shall not be valid against any mortgagee, purchaser, or judgment creditor until notice has been filed in the office of the judge of probate as provided under section 40-1-2 of the Code of Alabama, 1975. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 14, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-95. - Collection of delinquent taxes. 
    At any time within three (3) years after any amount herein required to be collected has become due and payable and any time within three (3) years after the delinquency of any tax, the city may bring an action in any appropriate court to collect the amount delinquent, together with penalties and interest. In such action a writ of attachment may issue, and no bond or affidavit previous to the issuing of said attachment is required. In such action a certificate by the city showing the delinquency shall be prima facie evidence of the determination of the amount due hereunder, of the delinquency and of the compliance by the department with all the provisions of this article in relation to the computation and determination of such amount. 
    In any action brought under the provisions of this article, process may be served as in other cases or may be served upon any agent or clerk in the State of Alabama, employed by any seller in a place of business maintained by such seller in the State of Alabama, or upon any agent or any seller soliciting business or accepting orders within the State of Alabama, in which case a copy of the process shall forthwith be sent by certified or registered mail to the seller at his principal or home office. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 15, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-96. - Examination of taxpayer and his books. 
    The city may summon before it any taxpayer and any officer or employee of any taxpayer, liable for taxes under this article of any other witnesses, swear and examine them with regard to any facts showing the amount of taxes levied by this article due by such persons, and the city or its duly authorized representatives and agents shall be allowed to examine any books, papers or documents of the taxpayer, and if any taxpayer shall refuse to allow such examination to be made in his main office or principal place of business in Alabama, the city may require the production, before it at the courthouse in the county in Alabama where the taxpayer has his main office or principal place of business, of any books, papers, invoices, or documents. The summons of witnesses to appear before it, or the notice to the taxpayer to produce books, papers, invoices or documents before it, may be issued by the city, signed by the city manager, and such summons or notice shall be directed to any sheriff of the State of Alabama, and must be served by any sheriff to whom such summons or notice is delivered by the city for services. 
    The city or any authorized agent is given full authority to inspect or examine, during business hours at the office of the taxpayer where its books are kept, or if said books are kept outside of the city, then at the office outside of the city where such books are kept by the taxpayer, all books, papers, invoices or documents of said taxpayer shedding any light on the amount of taxes levied by this article due by such person. 
    Any person who willfully fails to appear before the city after having been summoned as a witness, or having appeared refuses to testify as to any material matters required of him by the city, or any taxpayer or his agent who refuses to produce before the city after notice given him, any books, papers, invoices or documents required to be produced, or any taxpayer or agent thereof in custody of the books, papers, invoices or documents, and any taxpayer who refuses to allow the city or any authorized agent thereof to inspect or examine said books, papers, invoices or documents at the office of such taxpayer, where said books are kept during business hours, shall be guilty of contempt and upon a certificate of the facts to a circuit judge of the county where the taxpayer has his principal place of business or where his books are kept, it shall be the duty of such circuit judge to adjudge such taxpayer or his agent in contempt, and shall subject such taxpayer or his agent to a fine not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) and imprisonment in the county jail for a period not exceeding five (5) days; provided, that each said refusal to appear or upon appearance each refusal to testify, or each said refusal to produce books, papers, invoices or documents required, or each refusal to allow the examination of such books, records, invoices or documents, either or all, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 16, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-97. - Violator may be restrained from continuing in business. 
    Any taxpayer who shall violate any of the provisions of this article may be restrained from continuing in business, and the proper prosecution shall be instituted by and in the name of the city until such person shall have complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 17, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-98. - City authorized to determine true amount of tax due; penalties. 
    If the city is not satisfied with the return and payment of the tax or the amount of tax herein required to be paid to the city by any person, it is hereby authorized and empowered to compute and determine the amount required to be paid based upon the facts contained in the return or upon any information within its possession or that shall come into its possession. All amounts determined to be due under the provisions of this section shall bear interest at the rate of one-half (1/2) of one per cent per month, or fraction thereof, from the twentieth day after the close of the period or periods, as the case may be, for which such amounts were required to be reported to the city until paid. If any part of the deficiency for which a determination of an additional amount due is made is due to negligence or intentional disregard of this article or authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of ten (10) per cent of such amount shall be added thereto. If any part of the deficiency for which a determination of an additional amount due is made is due to fraud or an intent to evade this article or authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of twenty-five (25) per cent of such amount shall be added thereto. The city shall give to the retailer or person storing, using or consuming tangible personal property written notice of its determination. Such notice may be served personally or by mail. If by mail, said notice shall be addressed to the retailer or person storing, using or consuming tangible personal property at his address as the same appears in the records of the city and sent by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 18, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-99. - Estimate of tax due where no return made; penalties. 
    If any person neglects or refuses to make a return required to be made by this article, the city shall make an estimate for the period or periods in respect to which such person failed to make a return, based upon any information in its possession or that may come into its possession, of the amount of the total sales price of tangible personal property sold or purchased by such person, the storage, use or other consumption of which in the city is subject to the tax imposed by this article, and upon the basis of said estimate compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the city, adding to the sum thus arrived at a penalty equal to ten (10) per cent thereof. All amounts determined to be due under the provisions of this section shall bear interest at the rate of one-half of one per cent per month, or fraction thereof, from the twentieth day after the close of the period or periods, as the case may be, for which such amounts were required to be reported to the city until paid. If the neglect or refusal of any person to file a return as required by this article was due to fraud or an intent to evade this article or rules and regulations hereunder, a penalty of twenty-five (25) per cent of the amount required to be paid by such person shall be added thereto in addition to the ten (10) per cent penalty as above provided. Promptly thereafter the city shall give to such person written notice of such estimate, determination and penalty, the notice to be served personally or by mail in the same manner as prescribed for service of notice by the provisions of the preceding section of this article. The city, if good and sufficient reason is shown, may waive and remit the ten (10) per cent penalty or any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 19, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-100. - Interest; discounts. 
(a)  All taxes or amounts herein required to be collected not paid to the city on the date when the same becomes due and payable shall bear interest at the rate of one-half (1/2) of one per cent per month, or a fraction thereof, from and after the date when the same became due and payable until paid. 
(b)  Discounts in the amount of five (5) per cent on the first one hundred dollars ($100.00) or less in taxes and in the amount of two (2) per cent of any tax over one hundred dollars ($100.00), if any, are allowed up to a maximum total discount of five hundred sixty-two dollars ($562.00) paid before becoming delinquent. No discount shall be allowed if not paid when due. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 20, 12-7-91; Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 12-101. - Penalty for fraud or evasion. 
    If fraud or evasion on the part of any person is discovered by the city, it shall determine the amount by which the city has been defrauded, shall add to the amount so determined a penalty equal to twenty-five (25) per cent thereof, and shall determine the same to be due from such person. All amounts determined to be due from any person under the provisions of this section shall bear interest at the rate of one-half (1/2) of one per cent per month, or fraction thereof, from the twentieth day after the close of the period or periods, as the case may be, for which such amounts should have been paid. The amount so determined shall be immediately due and payable and if not paid within ten (10) days after the service upon such person of notice of the amount determined to be due, the delinquency penalty and interest provided in section 12-98 of this article shall attach thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 21, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-102. - Penalties. 
    Any seller or other person failing or refusing to furnish any return hereby required to be made, or failing or refusing to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the city, or rendering a false or fraudulent return, shall be subject to a fine of not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such offense. Any person required to make, render, sign, or verify any report as aforesaid who makes any false or fraudulent return, with intent to defeat or evade the determination of an amount due required by law to be made, shall for each such offense be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or be imprisoned not exceeding one year in the city jail, or be subject to both said fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. Any violation of the provisions of this article, except as otherwise herein provided, shall be punishable as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 22, 12-7-91) 
Sec. 12-103. - Existing sales/use tax. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to relieve any person from any tax liability, penalty, interest or forfeiture incurred under any laws or ordinances of the city prior to the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 23, 12-7-91) 
ARTICLE V. - TAX ON RENTERS OR LESSORS OF TANGIBLE PERSONAL PROPERTY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1982, adopted Feb. 20, 2001, was not specifically amendatory to the Code. The editor has treated these new provisions as superseding §§ 12-104-12-107, which contained similar provisions and which derived from Ord. No. 884, adopted Dec. 16, 1975. 

Sec. 12-104. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the following respective meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Business means all activities engaged in, or caused to be engaged in, with the object of gain, profit, benefit or advantage, either direct or indirect, and not excepting subactivities producing marketable commodities used or consumed in the main business activity, each of which subactivities shall be considered business engaged in, taxable in the classification in which it falls. 
    City means the City of Auburn, Alabama or the corporate boundaries of the City of Auburn, as applicable. 
    City manager means the duly appointed city manager of the city or, in his/her absence, the person performing the duties of the city manager. 
    Gross proceeds means the value proceeding or accruing from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property, without any deduction on account of the cost of the property so leased or rented, the cost of the materials used, labor or service cost, interest paid or any other expense whatsoever, and without any deduction on account of loss, and shall also include on the part of any person claiming exemption under the Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-223, as amended, an amount equal to the rental paid on any tangible personal property acquired under such exemption and thereafter diverted to the use of the person. 
    Leasing or rental means a transaction whereunder the person who owns or controls the possession of tangible personal property permits another person to have possession or use thereof for a consideration and for the duration of a definite or indefinite period of time without transfer of the title to such property. 
    Person means any natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, receiver, trust, estate or other entity, or any other group or combinations of any therefore acting as a unit. 
    Tangible personal property means the personal property which may be seen, weighed, measured, felt or touched, or is in any manner perceptible to the senses. The term "tangible personal property" shall not include stocks, bonds, notes, insurance or other contracts or securities. 
(Ord. No. 1982, § 1, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 12-105. - Rental fee levy and amount. 
    There is hereby levied and imposed in addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, a privilege or license fee upon each person engaging or continuing in this city in the business of leasing or renting tangible personal property at the rate of two and one-half (2 1/2) percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor from the lease or rental of tangible personal property; provided, that the said fee on each person engaging or continuing in this city in the business of leasing or renting any automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer for a period of twelve months or longer shall be at the rate of one and one fourth (1 1/4) percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor from the lease or rental of such automotive vehicle or truck trailer, semitrailer or house trailer; provided further, that the fee levied in this article shall not apply to any leasing or rental, as lessor, by the State of Alabama, or any municipality or county in the State of Alabama, including without limiting the generality of the foregoing, any corporation organized under provisions of the Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-54-80 through 11-54-101, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1982, § 2, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 12-106. - Monthly report and payment. 
(a)  The fee levied under provision of this article shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the fee accrues. On or before the twentieth day of each month, every person on whom the amounts levied by this article are imposed shall render to the city, on a form prescribed by the city, a true and correct statement showing the gross proceeds of such person's business, for the next preceding month the amount of gross receipts which are not subject to the fee or are not to be used as a measurement of the amounts due by such person, and the nature thereof, together with such other information as the city may require; and at the time of making such monthly report such person shall compute the fee due and shall pay to the city the amount shown to be due. 
(b)  If any person subject to this article should fail to pay the fee imposed herein, or should fail to render any report required hereby or should willfully make a false statement of fact in the statement or return required hereunder, such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of the Code of the City of Auburn. 
(Ord. No. 1982, § 3, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 12-107. - Effective date. 
    This article shall be effective April 1, 2001, upon its approval by the city council, or upon its otherwise becoming law, but shall, nonetheless, be published as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1982, § 4, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 12-108. - Reports of cash and credit rentals. 
    Any person taxable under this article, making cash and credit leases or rentals, may if he desires, report such cash leases or rentals only, and he shall thereafter include in each monthly report all cash and credit collections made during the month preceding, and shall pay the privilege license tax due thereon at the time of filing such report. 
(Ord. No. 884, § 5, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 12-109. - Records. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person engaging in or continuing in any business for which a privilege tax is imposed by this article to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross proceeds of any such business and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax for which he is liable under the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of every person to keep and preserve for a period of three (3) years, all invoices of gross proceeds proceeding or accruing from the leasing or rental herein taxed; and all such books, invoices, and other records shall be open for examination at any time by the city manager or his authorized representative. Any person leasing who in addition leases for re-leasing shall keep his books so as to show separately the gross proceeds of leasing and the gross proceeds of leasing for re-leasing. 
(b)  The books, records and accounts mentioned above shall at all times be open to examination by the city manager or his authorized representative, upon request by the city manager. Upon demand by the city manager or his authorized representative, it shall be the duty of any person subject to this license tax to submit to the city manager or his authorized representative, for inspection and examination, during reasonable business hours, in the city, all books of account. Each occurrence of a failure to keep records, or allow examination thereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 884, §§ 6, 7, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 12-110. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall fail to keep records as required by this article or who shall refuse to permit their examination or who violates any other provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense against the city and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 884, § 7, 12-16-75) 
Secs. 12-111-12-126. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MOTOR FUELS TAX[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 22; vehicles for hire, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- State gasoline tax, Code of Ala., § 40-17-30 et seq. 

Sec. 12-127. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motor fuels shall mean gasoline, diesel oil, tractor fuel, gas oil, distillate or liquefied gas, kerosene, naphtha, or other liquefied motor fuels or any device or substitute therefor, commonly used in internal combustion engines; however, nothing in this article shall be held to apply to those products known commercially as "kerosene oil," "fuel oil" or "crude oil," when used for lighting, heating or industrial purposes. 
    Person shall mean any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, receiver, trustee, entity, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, in the plural as well as the singular number, unless the intention to give a more limited meaning is disclosed by the context. 
    Seller shall mean every person who shall sell, deliver or distribute or who shall engage in the business of selling, distributing, or delivering motor fuels within the police jurisdiction of the city, including the territory within the corporate limits thereof. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 3-23-76) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-128. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any seller of motor fuels to make any sale or delivery of motor fuels within the city or the police jurisdiction thereof without first obtaining the license required by this article from the city manager and any such seller who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be guilty of an offense against the city and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of this Code. In addition to being required to pay the tax levied and set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 7, 3-23-76) 
Sec. 12-129. - Levied; rate. 
    Every seller shall obtain a license, unless exempt therefrom as hereinafter provided, and shall pay in installments and at the times hereinafter provided, an amount equivalent to two cents ($0.02) for each and every gallon of motor fuel sold, delivered or distributed within the corporate limits of the city and in an amount equivalent to one cent ($0.01) for each and every gallon of motor fuel sold, delivered or distributed without or beyond the corporate limits of the city but within the police jurisdiction of the city. The license shall extend and be valid so long as there shall be no default in making and filing of statements required hereunder or in the making of the payments of the tax as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 2, 3-23-76) 
State Law reference- Authority to require distributor, etc., to pay municipality's gasoline tax, Code of Ala., § 40-17-1. 
Sec. 12-130. - Tax additional. 
    The tax assessed and levied under this article shall not affect or interfere with in any way that certain tax levied by Ordinance No. 885, adopted by reference in section 12-16, being the general license ordinance, but shall be in additional thereto. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 5, 3-23-76) 
Sec. 12-131. - Not applicable to certain sales. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any sales, deliveries or distributions of motor fuels required to be exempt from tax by the interstate commerce clause of the United States Constitution, nor shall the provisions of this article apply to aviation fuel. As used in this section the term "aviation fuel" shall have the meaning assigned to it in Code of Alabama, Section 40-17-31. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 6, 3-23-76) 
State Law reference- Aviation fuel exemption required, Code of Ala., § 40-17-50. 
Sec. 12-132. - Certain sales exempt. 
    A seller or distributor of motor fuel who shall have procured or obtained the motor fuel which he may sell or deliver from another seller who shall have paid the tax thereon as herein fixed shall not be required to pay the license or privilege tax as herein fixed for the sale or delivery of such gasoline so obtained by him. Such seller or distributor of motor fuel who shall claim the exemption under this section shall, however, upon the written request of the city manager file on or before the twentieth day of the following month a sworn written statement showing the name of the person from whom the purchase was made during the previous month and the date on which the purchase was made, and the amount of such purchase. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 3, 3-23-76) 
Sec. 12-133. - When due. 
(a)  Each and every seller shall, no or before the twentieth day of each and every month, file with the city manager a sworn statement which shall be a full, true, accurate and correct statement of the amount and quantity of all motor fuel sold, distributed or delivered by him within the corporate limits of the city and, in a separate column or space, of the amount in quantity of all motor fuel sold, distributed or delivered by him within the police jurisdiction of the city, but beyond and the corporate limits thereof during the preceding calendar month. 
(b)  At the time of filing of the statement the seller shall pay to the city an amount equivalent to two cents ($0.02) for each gallon of motor fuel sold, distributed or delivered by him within the corporate limits of the city during the preceding calendar month, and an amount equivalent to one cent ($0.01) for each gallon of motor fuel sold, distributed or delivered by him beyond the corporate limits of the city but within its police jurisdiction during the preceding calendar month. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 5, 3-23-76) 
Sec. 12-134. - Sellers using machines; right to inspect machines. 
    Each and every seller who makes use of machines or other devices for dispensing or delivering gasoline shall, before being granted a license hereunder and before engaging in such business, make application in writing to the city stating the name of the seller, the location of his business in the city or its police jurisdiction, and the number of dispensing machines or devices to be used. In addition, each and every seller by applying for such license and beginning business within the city shall be deemed to have consented to and granted to the city and its duly authorized agents, servants, and employees the right to inspect such machine, pump, and other devices for dispensing or delivering gasoline during the hours of the day the business is open to the public. This right to inspect the machines, pumps, and other devices for dispensing of delivering gasoline shall apply to the seller's retailers, as well as to the seller making application for the license under this article. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 4, 3-23-76) 
Sec. 12-135. - Penalties for failure to file, collect, etc. 
(a)  Any seller who shall fail or omit to make or file any statement provided for or required by this article or who shall make any false statement in respect thereto, or who shall refuse to allow the city, its agents, servants, or employees, to inspect or read the meter on his machines, pumps, or other devices for dispensing or delivering gasoline as required by section 12-134, shall be guilty of an offense against the city of auburn, and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of this Code. Each and every day that passes after the time fixed by this article for the filing of such written statement until the statement is filed as required, shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(b)  Upon the commission of any such offense as set out in this article, the governing body of the city shall have the right and power to revoke the license under which such seller is operating. 
(c)  In addition, any license tax not paid by the time herein fixed shall be increased by an additional sum to two (2) per cent as a penalty for filing, which penalty shall be payable and collected as any other license penalties. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 8, 3-23-76) 
Sec. 12-136. - Use of collected funds. 
    The proceeds of the taxes prescribed in this article, when collected, shall be used as follows: 
(1)  One-half of all sums collected under this article shall be dedicated to and used for the construction and improvements of streets within the city and its police jurisdiction, including but not limited to the costs of materials, labor, repayment or retirement of debts incurred for materials, labor or for the construction, improvement, repair and lighting of streets, sidewalks, rights-of-way, street signs, traffic-control devices, and the installation, relocation and removal of all public utilities in, over, and across the streets and rights-of-way, and the payment of the principal of, interest on, and redemption price, including any premium, of any bonds, warrants, notes, and other obligations and securities that may be issued by the city for the purpose of construction and improvement of streets within the city and its police jurisdiction, and accumulation of reserve for such payment. 
(2)  The remaining one-half of all sums collected under this article shall be deposited in the city's general fund and this shall be used by the city as directed by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 9, 3-23-76) 
Cross reference- Street construction, § 21-16 et seq.; traffic, Ch. 22. 
Secs. 12-137-12-152. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - CIGARETTE LICENSE TAX[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- State cigarette tax, Code of Ala., § 40-25-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-153. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning, the following words and phrases wherever used in this article shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section. Any words or phrases used in this article and not herein defined, which are defined by Title 40, chapter 25, of the Code of Alabama, 1975, shall have the meanings given to them by that section. 
    Cigarette shall mean a roll of finely cut tobacco or any substitute therefor, enclosed in paper prepared for smoking by individuals. 
    Dealer shall mean any wholesale or retail dealer as herein defined. 
    Package shall mean individual containers for which or in which retail sales of cigarettes are normally made or intended to be made. 
    Retail dealer shall mean any person other than a wholesale dealer, who sells or delivers cigarettes within the city or its police jurisdiction and any person operating under a retail dealer's license. 
    Retail price shall mean the retail selling price of the cigarettes before adding the amount of tax assessed herein or any tobacco tax assessed by the state. 
    Sale shall mean any transfer of title or possession or both, or any exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by any means whatsoever, for a consideration or any agreement therefor, including rewards, prizes or premiums of cigarettes given as a result of operation on punchboards, shooting galleries, or other activities. 
    Stamps shall mean the stamps by the use of which the license taxes levied under this article are paid. 
    Store shall mean the storage or warehousing of cigarettes in any manner, or the withdrawal or use of the same for any purpose, other than for resale or reshipment outside the city or its police jurisdiction. 
    Wholesale dealer shall mean a person who sells or delivers within the city or its police jurisdiction at wholesale only, cigarettes to retail dealers for the purpose of resale only. 
(Code 1956, § 13-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-154. - License tax levy in city. 
    In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, every person who sells, stores or delivers cigarettes shall pay a license tax to the city, and a license tax is hereby fixed and levied for the sale, storage or delivery of cigarettes in the corporate limits of the city, which license tax shall be in an amount equal to two (2) mills per cigarette so sold, stored or delivered. 
(Code 1956, § 13-2; Ord. No. 1037, § 1, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 1164, § 1, 9-18-84) 
Sec. 12-155. - License tax levy in police jurisdiction. 
    In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, every person who sells, stores or delivers cigarettes shall pay a license tax to the city, and a license tax is hereby fixed and levied for the sale, storage or delivery of cigarettes in the police jurisdiction, which license tax shall be in an amount equal to one mill per cigarette so sold, stored or delivered. 
(Code 1956, § 13-3; Ord. No. 1037, § 2, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 1164, § 2, 9-18-84) 
Sec. 12-156. - Sale and price of stamps. 
    The city clerk shall keep on hand for sale an adequate quantity of stamps to be affixed to each package of cigarettes in denominations as required under this article. Each such stamp shall have inscribed thereon the words "City of Auburn Tobacco Tax," but the words need not be arranged in the foregoing order and may be abbreviated. The stamps may be sold to wholesale dealers by the city clerk at a price equal to ninety (90) per cent of the full amount thereof, the remaining ten (10) per cent of such full amount representing compensation to the wholesale dealer for the labor of affixing such stamps to the package in which the cigarettes are contained; however, the city clerk is authorized to sell such stamps to retail dealers on the same items where the number of stamps sold in each such transaction shall be ten thousand (10,000) or more. All other persons, except such wholesale dealers and retail dealers buying stamps in lots less than ten thousand (10,000), must pay the full amount of the stamps, but no person shall be entitled to purchase any such number of stamps as shall cause the purchase price to include a fraction of a cent. 
(Code 1956, § 13-4) 
Sec. 12-157. - Affixing of stamps. 
(a)  Before any cigarettes shall be sold, stored or delivered within the corporate limits of the city or its police jurisdiction by any dealer, such dealer shall affix to each package of cigarettes a stamp or stamps, obtained from the city clerk in the amounts set out in this article, in payment of the license taxes imposed by this article. Every dealer shall, within one hour after receipt of any cigarettes within the city or its police jurisdiction, unless sooner offered for sale, cause stamps to the requisite amount of the tax to be affixed as herein provided and shall cause the same to be cancelled by writing or stamping with waterproof ink across the face of each stamp such registered number as shall be furnished to such dealer by the city clerk. 
(b)  After such stamping has been begun it shall be continued with reasonable diligence by such dealer until all unstamped cigarettes shall have been stamped, and the stamps cancelled as herein provided, but no stamp required to be affixed to any package of cigarettes shall, after the same has been affixed as herein provided, be again used in payment of any part of the tax levied under this article. Such stamps shall be affixed in such manner that their removal will require continued application of water or steam. 
(c)  In the case of cigarettes sold by retail in packages, the stamps shall be affixed to each individual package in such a way that such stamps shall be torn in two (2) or mutilated when such package is open. 
(Code 1956, § 13-5) 
Sec. 12-158. - Records of wholesaler and retailer. 
    Every wholesale dealer shall, at the time of selling or delivering cigarettes into the city or its police jurisdiction, make a true duplicate invoice of the same, which shall show full and complete details of the sale or delivery of such cigarettes and the prices thereof. Every wholesale dealer and every retail dealer shall keep a record of the purchase, sale, exchange or receipt of cigarettes. All such invoices and cancelled checks and other memoranda pertaining to any such purchase, sale, exchange or receipt shall be retained for a period of three (3) years and shall be subject to inspection of the city clerk or his duly authorized deputy or the city license inspector, who shall have the power and authority to enter upon the premises of any dealer at all reasonable times for the purpose of examining such invoices, records, cancelled checks, and other memoranda. Any person who purchases or receives in any manner whatsoever cigarettes which do not have stamps affixed in the manner required by this article shall, within three (3) days after receipt of such cigarettes, report the receipt and purchase thereof to the city clerk giving the date of purchase or receipt, the name of the persons from whom purchased or received, and a list describing the cigarettes so purchased or received, and the purchase price thereof. Such receipt must be made by registered mail or in person. 
(Code 1956, § 13-6) 
Secs. 12-159-12-174. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - LODGING TAX[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- State lodging tax, Code of Ala., § 40-26-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-175. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning, the words, terms and phrases used in this article shall have the following respective meanings: 
    City manager shall mean the city manager of Auburn. 
    Police jurisdiction shall mean the territory outside the corporate limits of the city but within its police jurisdiction. 
    Person shall mean any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, administrator, trustee or other fiduciary or personal representative. 
    Transient shall mean a person to whom rooms or lodging is rented for a period of less than thirty (30) continuous days. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 1, 5-21-74) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-176. - Levied. 
    The business of renting or furnishing any room or rooms or lodgings to transients in any hotel, motel, inn, apartment, house, condominium, tourist camp, tourist cabin, mobile or modular home in which rooms or lodgings are regularly furnished to transients for periods of less than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days for a consideration, said license tax to be in an amount equal to seven (7) per cent of the charge for such room, rooms, or lodgings, including the charge for the use or rental of personal property and services furnished in such rooms; provided, that charges for property sold or services furnished which are required to be included in the computation of the tax levided in Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-23-1 et seq., as amended and as may be amended, shall not be included in the computation of the license or tax levied herein. Of the amount of this privilege or license tax (lodging tax) remitted to the City of Auburn, one-seventh ( 1/7 ) shall be remitted to the Auburn-Opelika Convention and Visitors Bureau for the bureau's use in funding its operations. This seven (7) per cent tax shall be in addition to any privilege or license or lodging tax imposed by the State of Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 1, 5-21-74; Ord. No. 1059, § 2, 10-6-81; Ord. No. 1133, § 1, 9-6-83; Ord. No. 1294, § 1, 10-4-88; Ord. No. 1851, § 2, 8-17-99; Ord. No. 2356, § 1, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 12-177. - Due date of taxes and monthly reports. 
    The taxes levied under the provisions of this article, except as otherwise provided, shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the tax accrues. On or before the twentieth day of each month, every person on whom the taxes herein levied are imposed shall render to the city manager, on a form prescribed by the city manager, a true and correct statement showing the gross proceeds of the business subject to the tax for the then next preceding month, together with such other information as the city manager may demand and require. At the time of making such monthly report the taxpayer shall compute the taxes due and shall pay to the city manager the amount of taxes shown to be due. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 3, 5-21-74; Ord. No. 850, § 1, 7-30-74) 
Sec. 12-178. - Credit collections. 
    Any person subject to the taxes herein levied who conducts business on a credit basis may defer reporting credit rentals and charges until after their collection, and in the event he so defers reporting them, he shall thereafter include in each monthly report all credit collections made during the then preceding month and shall pay the amount of taxes measured thereby at the time of filing such report. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 4, 5-21-74) 
Sec. 12-179. - Annual returns. 
    On or before thirty (30) days after the end of each calendar year, each person subject to the taxes as herein levied shall file with the city manager a return, verified by oath, showing the gross proceeds of business done during such calendar year; shall compute the amount of tax chargeable against such person in accordance with the provisions of this article; shall deduct the amount of monthly payments made as hereinbefore provided, if any have been made; and pay to the city manager with the report the residue of the taxes herein levied that are chargeable against such person. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 5, 5-21-74) 
Sec. 12-180. - Maintenance of records. 
    It shall be the duty of every person engaging or continuing in any business to the taxes herein levied to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross proceeds of such business and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax for which he is liable under the provisions of this article. Such records shall be kept and preserved for a period of two (2) years and shall be open for examination at any time by the city manager or other duly authorized representative of the city. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 6, 5-21-74) 
Sec. 12-181. - Oaths. 
    The monthly reports herein required to be submitted are not required to be made on oath; but the annual returns provided for in section 12-179 shall be sworn to by the taxpayer or his agent before some officer authorized to administer oaths; and any false statement of a material fact made with intent to defraud shall constitute perjury, and upon conviction thereof the person so convicted shall be punished as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 7, 5-21-74) 
Sec. 12-182. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person subject to the provisions of this article who for any reason fails to make the reports as herein required, who fails to keep the records as herein required, or who fails to pay the amount due the city within the time limits as herein required, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of this Code. Each month of such failure shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person subject to the provisions of this article who willfully refuses to make the reports as herein required, or who refuses to permit the examination of his or its records by the city manager, or other duly authorized agent of the city, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. Each month of failure to make such report shall constitute a separate offense, and each refusal of a written demand of the city manager to examine, inspect or audit such records shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 8, 5-21-74) 
Sec. 12-183. - Interest and penalty. 
    Any person who fails to pay the tax herein levied within the time required shall pay, in addition to the tax, a penalty of ten (10) per cent of the amount of tax due, together with interest thereon at the rate of one-half of one per cent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date on which the tax herein levied became due and payable, such penalty and interest to be assessed and collected as part of the tax; provided that the governing body of the city may, if a good and sufficient reason is shown, waive or remit the penalty or any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 9, 5-21-74) 
Sec. 12-184. - Use of proceeds. 
    The proceeds derived from the taxes herein levied shall be placed in the general fund of the city, subject to appropriation by the governing body of the city for any lawful purpose of the city. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 10, 5-21-74) 
Secs. 12-185-12-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PAWNBROKERS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1349, adopted March 20, 1990, has been included herein as superseding the provisions formerly codified as Ch. 12, Art. IX, §§ 12-201-12-209 and 12-221-12-229. These former provisions pertained to similar subject matter and were derived from Ord. No. 1033, §;s 1-14, adopted Oct. 21, 1980; and Ord. No. 1156, § 1, adopted May 15, 1984. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-201. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall be binding upon every employee or agent of the buyer of the articles described herein and it shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any such licensee or his agents, servants, officers or employees to fail or refuse to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 1, 3-20-90; Ord, No. 1398, § 1, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-202. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of their article: 
    Applicant. The word "applicant," when used in this article, shall include the plural where applicable, and all agents, officers, servants or employees of the applicant in the city, if the applicant is other than a sole proprietor. 
    Pawnbroker. A person, either owner or manger, or employee whose business is to lend money for security of personal tangible property deposited with him or left in pawn. 
    Second hand dealer. A person, either owner or manager, or employee whose business is to purchase or take in second hand items for trade or to resell. 
    Second hand goods. Any tangible item of personal property either pawned, taken on trade, sold or kept on consignment for sale including, but not limited to, gold, silver, jewelry, household articles, furnishings, personal effects, bric-a-brac, settings for gems, watches, flatware, service sets, scrap metals, electronic equipment, music compact discs (CDs), tapes, records, digital video discs (DVDs), video games or equipment, televisions, firearms, musical instruments, bicycles, all terrain vehicles (ATVs), golf carts, tools, construction equipment or like personal property (excluding textbooks, clothing, and motorized vehicles or vessels titled by any state). 
(Ord. No. 1349, §§ 2-5, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, §§ 2, 3, 8-6-91; Ord. No. 2690, § 1, 12-21-10) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-203. - Registration with police. 
    Each licensee, pawnbroker, or second hand dealer under this article shall promptly, but no later than five (5) days after the beginning of business, register with the chief of police, in a book kept for such purpose, his name, permanent and/or temporary address, and every place where he carries on business or stores property. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 15, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 13, 8-6-91; Ord. No. 2690, § 2, 12-21-10) 
Sec. 12-204. - Record to be kept by buyer. 
    Each licensee, pawnbroker, or second hand dealer under this article purchasing, or receiving in pawn, gold, silver or other tangible property in any form set out herein shall keep a book in which shall be entered promptly the following information: 
(1)  The name of the person or entity from which the article is purchased. 
(2)  The date and hour of the purchase. 
(3)  The residence or place of business of such person or entity. 
(4)  Identification of such person or entity to include sex, race, date of birth, driver's license, social security number or other reliable identification of such person. 
(5)  Detailed description of the gold, silver, second hand goods, or other tangible items of personal property pawned or purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 16, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 14, 8-6-91; Ord. No. 2690, § 3, 12-21-10) 
Sec. 12-205. - Transcript to chief of police. 
    Each licensee, pawnbroker, or second hand dealer shall, before the conclusion of each business day, submit to the chief of police via the reporting system designated by the chief of police, entries of all business done during the business day immediately preceding the filing of the entry. Said entry shall contain a description of the gold, silver, second hand goods, or other tangible personal property purchased, taken in trade, or pawned, and shall include all other information as set out herein, or as required by the designated reporting system. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 17, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 15, 8-6-91; Ord. No. 2690, § 4, 12-21-10) 
Sec. 12-206. - Identification of articles purchased or pawned. 
    Each licensee, pawnbroker, or second hand dealer under this article purchasing or receiving in trade or in pawn, gold, second hand goods, or other tangible property in any form set out herein shall attach to or place on each article purchased a tag or other identifying mark or label numbered to correspond with the serial number of the book entry required herein to be kept, except when small articles are bought in bulk and are too numerous to conveniently tag or mark individually then an identifying number shall be placed on the container or wrapper in which the articles are kept or placed. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 18, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 16, 8-6-91; Ord. No. 2690, § 5, 12-21-10) 
Sec. 12-207. - Time articles to be held after purchase. 
    The property of the kind described herein shall be held within the corporate limits of the city by the licensee and/or pawnbroker in the same form, shape or condition in which it was purchased, without mutilation, melting, reduction to block or lump form, or destruction of the form thereof, for a period of ninety-six (96) hours after the hour when the licensee and/or pawnbroker reports the purchase to the chief of police or such officer of the public safety department, police division, as may be delegated to make such examination or inspection, unless permission for change in form or sale is obtained in writing from the chief of police after the filing of the report required herein. This section shall not apply to articles pawned. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 19, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 17, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-208. - Inspection of records of licensee and/or pawnbroker. 
    The books and records kept by each licensee and/or pawnbroker of the articles described herein shall be open for inspection at all times by the chief of police or by any officers of the public safety department, police division, and the licensee and/or pawnbroker and his agents and employees shall at all times exhibit the book to such officers on request. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 20, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 18, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-209. - Seller to furnish accurate information. 
    Any seller of articles described herein shall give accurate, true and correct facts to the dealer of all information required under this article. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 21, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 19, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-210. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article or who shall do business within the city without first obtaining a permit or license as provided herein shall upon conviction be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 22, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 20, 8-6-91) 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1-9. 
Secs. 12-211-12-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-221. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to conduct, purchase, or operate as a licensee, pawn broker or second hand dealer by purchasing or receiving in pawn any tangible item of personal property including, but not limited to second hand goods as defined above within the city without first paying to the city manager the license tax herein described and procuring a license from the designated officer of the City of Auburn. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 6, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 4, 8-6-91; Ord. No. 2690, § 6, 12-21-10) 
Sec. 12-222. - License tax rate. 
    The license tax hereby levied against buyers against buyers as described herein shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each calendar year or any fraction thereof. There shall be no reduced license for any period less than the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 7, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 5, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-223. - Application. 
    Applicants for license under this article shall file with the city manager a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by the city, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and physical description of the applicant; 
(2)  Date of birth of the applicant, and driver's license number, if the applicant has a driver's license; 
(3)  Full local address of the applicant, and the length of time the applicant has resided within the city; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the employer-employee relationship; 
(5)  The applicant must provide the nature of second hand goods to be bought, sold, or received in pawn. 
(6)  The length of time for which the right to purchase or receive in pawn is desired and the location where such is to be done; 
(7)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing the application, which picture shall be no smaller than two inches by two inches (2" × 2") showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(8)  The fingerprints of the applicant, and the names of at least two (2) reliable property owners of the county who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business respectability or, in lieu of the names of such references, such other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to property evaluate such character and business responsibility; 
(9)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal criminal ordinance in any state, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(10)  The names, local addresses, driver's license numbers, if any, and physical descriptions of all employees of the applicant; 
(11)  The applicant must have the ability to access internet on site at the place of business and to report to the chief of police via an electronic reporting system, should such a system be so designated by the chief of police; 
(12)  The applicant must agree to register with any electronic reporting system designated by the chief of police, and comply with the reporting system requirements within thirty (30) days of notification by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 8, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 6, 8-6-91; Ord. No. 2690, §§ 7, 8, 12-21-10) 
Sec. 12-224. - Investigation fee. 
    At the time of filing the application for the license, a fee of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars shall be paid to the city to cover the cost of an investigation of the facts stated therein. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 9, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 7, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-225. - Investigation generally. 
    Upon receipt of an application for license, the application shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business responsibility are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse the application with his approval and return it to the city manager. The city manager shall cause to be made such other reviews of the application as he deems necessary to determine compliance with applicable city ordinances and regulations and shall endorse the application with his approval or disapproval. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 10, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 8, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-226. - Issuance or denial. 
    When the application for license is approved by both the police chief and the city manager, the license shall be issued by the city manager to the applicant upon receipt of the required fee from the applicant. When the police chief or city manager, either one or both, disapprove the application, the city manager shall notify the applicant that his application has been denied and the reason for denial. In the event the license is denied, the applicant may appeal to the governing body of the city by filing a written appeal notice with the city manager within fourteen (14) days of the date of the date of the disapproval notice. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 11, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 9, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-227. - Signing and contents; display. 
    The license required by this article shall be serially numbered, shall contain the signature of the city manager, and shall show the name, address and photograph of the licensee, the date of issuance and length or time license shall be valid, and the location at which the purchasing is authorized to be conducted. Such license must be publicly displayed at all times whenever the applicant conducts business. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 12, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 10, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-228. - Record of licenses issued. 
    The city manager shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 13, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 11, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 12-229. - Special provisions for persons who hold jewelry licenses. 
    Any one who holds a current jewelry license issued by the city shall be exempt from the license fee established herein. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 14, 3-20-90; Ord. No. 1398, § 12, 8-6-91) 
Secs. 12-230-12-245. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SIDEWALK SALES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Peddlers, solicitors, etc., Ch. 16; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21. 

Sec. 12-246. - Charitable purposes. 
    No nonprofit organization shall conduct a sale of wares or merchandise on a public sidewalk for the purpose of receiving money for charitable or eleemosynary purposes within the boundaries of the entertainment district as defined in section 3-58 unless all of the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  Permission of the property owner adjacent to the site must be secured in advance of sale. 
(2)  Sales are allowed only during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 1, 4-4-72; Ord. No. 2936, § 1, 7-7-2015) 
Cross reference- Charitable solicitation from rights-of-way, § 16-3. 
Sec. 12-247. - Noncharitable purposes. 
    No person shall conduct a sale of wares or merchandise on a public right-of-way: 
(a)  Sidewalk sales may be permitted on a public sidewalk within the boundaries of the entertainment district as defined in section 3-58 during the following times and events: 
(1)  Sales sponsored or under the auspices of an organization such as the chamber of commerce, downtown merchants and property owner association or similar merchants' organization as a promotion festival, or event approved by the city council. 
(2)  Sales on Auburn University home football game weekends from Thursday through Sunday. 
(3)  Sales on Auburn University graduation day weekends from Thursday through Sunday. 
(4)  Community events where street closures are approved by the city council such as downtown trick or treat, Christmas parade, summer night art walk and similar downtown events and festivals. 
(5)  Sales on the day before, on, and the day after official city holidays including the first day of January, Martin Luther King Day, Memorial Day, the fourth day of July, Labor Day, Veterans Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. When holidays fall on a Monday or Friday both weekend days may be included in the sale. 
(6)  Sales during sales tax free holidays as designated by the city council. 
(b)  No person shall conduct a sale of wares or merchandise on a public sidewalk within the boundaries of the entertainment district as defined in section 3-58 unless all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  Sale and display of merchandise or wares shall be limited to the sidewalk immediately abutting the front of the property owner or merchant taking part in the promotional sale. 
(2)  Outside vendors shall not be permitted to take part in the promotional sale and the sale and display of merchandise or wares shall be limited to that of the property owner or merchant taking part in the promotional sale, provided however, that during community events specified in section 12-247(a)(4) above, outside vendors may be invited by the sponsoring organization to participate in the promotional sale. For the purposes of this article, outside vendor shall mean any vendor that does not have a physical business location within the entertainment district as defined in section 3-58. 
(3)  Sale and display of merchandise or wares may be located on up to one-half (1/2) of the sidewalk provided; however, that a minimum of five (5) feet shall be kept clear at all times for pedestrian traffic and accessibility. 
(4)  Sale and display of merchandise or wares shall not be located within two (2) feet of any stairways or ramps for pedestrian traffic and accessibility. 
(5)  Tables, displays or other objects with a leading edge over twenty-seven (27) inches in height from the sidewalk may not protrude more than four (4) inches horizontally into pedestrian circulation paths. 
(6)  Sale and display of merchandise or wares shall not be permitted in parking spaces or elsewhere in the right-of-way except during community events where street closures are approved by the city council. 
(7)  Participating merchants and/or the organization agree to indemnify, hold harmless, and defend the city for liability arising from their sale of wares or merchandise on a public sidewalk. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to nonprofit organizations conducting sales on public sidewalks for the purpose of receiving money for charitable or eleemosynary purposes. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to ticket scalpers registered according to section 16-52. 
(e)  It shall be a violation of this article for any vendor to compensate, by cash or in-kind services, a property owner or merchant in exchange for any agreement to display or sell merchandise or wares on a public sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 2, 4-4-72; Ord. No. 2936, § 1, 7-7-2015; Ord. No. 3051, § 1, 9-5-17) 
Secs. 12-248, 12-249. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT FACILITIES 

Sec. 12-250. - Definitions. 
    Adult book and video store. An establishment having as a significant or substantial portion of its stock in trade, books, videos, magazines, and other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting or relating to "specified sexual activities" or relating to "specified anatomical areas" as herein defined. 
    Adult entertainment business. Any person, association or establishment involved in the sale of services or products characterized by the exposure, presentation or representation of specified anatomical areas or physical contact of live males or females, and which is characterized by salacious conduct appealing to prurient interest for the observation or participation in by the patrons. Services or products included within the scope of adult entertainment business are photography, dancing, reading, massage, providing escorts or serving as an escort (as defined by this section), providing explicit sexual conversation for compensation whether by phone or in-person, and similar functions which utilize activities as specified above. 
    Adult entertainment facility. A facility having a significant portion of its function as adult entertainment which includes the following listed categories: Adult book and video store, adult entertainment business, adult mini motion picture theater, adult motion picture theater, adult paraphernalia store, escort agency and massage establishments. 
    Adult mini motion picture theater. A facility with a capacity of less than fifty (50) persons, used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult motion picture theater. A facility with a capacity of more than fifty (50) persons, used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult paraphernalia store. An establishment having as a significant portion of its stock in trade, mechanical and/or nonmechanical devices which are distinguished or characterized by their intended use for sexual arousal and/or massage of specified anatomical areas as herein defined. 
    Employee. Any person who performs any service on the premises of an adult entertainment facility on a full-time, part-time, or contract basis, regardless of whether the person is denominated as an employee, independent contractor, agent, or by another status. "Employee" does not include a person exclusively on the premises for repair or maintenance of the premises, or for the delivery of goods to the premises. 
    Escort. Any person who, for consideration, and for another person, agrees or offers: 
(1)  To act as a companion, guide, or date; or
