ARTICLE II. - WEEDS AND OTHER OBNOXIOUS CONDITIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to cut weeds at owner's expense, Code of Ala., § 11-47-140. 

Sec. 15-16. - Prohibited; nuisance declared. 
    Weeds shall be abated using the procedures outlined in Code of Alabama 1975 sections 11-67-90 through 11-67-95 listed below or Section 302.4 of the International Property Maintenance Code. 
    Other obnoxious conditions shall be abated as outlined in chapters 1 and 3 of the currently adopted edition of the International Property Maintenance Code as amended by the city. 
Section 11-67-90 
Article applicable only to certain Class 6 municipalities. 
This division shall apply only to a Class 6 municipality having an alternate council as provided in Section 11-43A-8, under the form of government provided in Article 1, Chapter 43A of this title. 
(Act 2012-440, p. 1241, §1.) 
Section 11-67-91 
Grass or weeds may be declared public nuisance and abated. 
(a)  An abundance of overgrown grass or weeds within the municipality which is injurious to the general public health, safety, and general welfare by providing breeding grounds and shelter for rats, mice, snakes, mosquitoes, and other vermin, insects, and pests; or attaining heights and dryness so as to constitute a serious fire threat and hazard; or bearing wingy or downy seeds, which when mature, cause the spread of weeds and, when breathed in, cause irritation of the throat, lungs, and eyes of the public; or hiding debris, such as broken glass or metal, which could inflict injury on a person going upon the property; or being unsightly; or growth of grass or weeds, other than ornamental plant growth, which exceeds 12 inches in height, may be declared to be a public nuisance and abated as provided in this division. 
(b)  This division shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  Heavily wooded areas in their natural state which are undeveloped. 
(2)  Farm properties. 
(3)  Properties under current construction. 
(Act 2012-440, p. 1241, §2.) 
Section 11-67-92 
Notice. 
(a)  Whenever in the opinion of the city official or any other city employee designated by the city manager, a nuisance exists, the official shall order the owner of the property on which the nuisance is located to abate the condition. 
(b)  The enforcing official shall give the owner written notice in person or by first class mail. The notice shall apprise the owner of the facts of the alleged nuisance and require the condition be abated within the time stated in the notice or to request a hearing before an administrative official of the city designated by the city manager, to determine whether there has been a violation. 
(c)  The notice shall be sent to that person shown by the records of the county to have been the last person assessed for payment of ad valorem tax on the property where the nuisance is situated. It shall be the responsibility of that person to promptly advise the enforcing official of a change of ownership or interest in the property. 
(d)  The notice shall also be posted in a conspicuous place on the property. 
(e)  The notice shall require the owner to complete abatement of the nuisance within 14 days from the date of notice, provided the enforcing official may stipulate additional time, but in no case more than 28 days. 
(f)  A property owner shall have five days in which to request a hearing before the administrative official to appeal the determination of the enforcing official. After the hearing, the enforcing official shall notify the owner by personal service or by first class mail of the determination of the administrative official. If the administrative official determines that a nuisance exists, the owner shall comply with the initial order to abate issued by the enforcing official, with modifications as may be made by the administrative official. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the administrative official at the hearing, within 10 days, may appeal to the circuit court upon filing with the clerk of the court notice of the appeal and bond for security of costs in the form and amount to be approved by the circuit clerk. Upon filing of the notice of appeal and approval of the bond, the clerk of the court shall serve a copy of the notice of appeal on the clerk of the municipality and the appeal shall be docketed in the court and shall be a preferred case therein. The clerk of the municipality, upon receiving the notice, shall file with the clerk of the court a copy of the findings and determination of the administrative official in its proceedings. Any trials shall be held without jury upon the determination of the administrative official that the weeds are a public nuisance. 
(Act 2012-440, p. 1241, §3.) 
Section 11-67-93 
Failure to abate condition; assessing cost of abatement. 
(a)  If the owner fails, neglects, or refuses to abate the condition after notice to do so, the enforcing official shall cause the offending grass or weeds to be cut. 
(b)  Upon completion of the abatement work performed by the municipality, including work by contractors employed by the municipality, the enforcing official shall compute the actual expenses, including, but not limited to, total wages paid, value of the use of equipment, advertising expenses, postage, and materials purchased, which were incurred by the municipality as a result of the work. An itemized statement of the expenses shall be given by first class mail to the last known address of the owner of the property. This notice shall be sent at least five days in advance of the city council meeting in which they will consider the assessment of the cost against property. 
(c)  At the time fixed for receiving and considering the statement, the council shall hear the same, together with any objections which may be raised by the owner whose property is liable to be assessed for the work and thereupon make modifications in the statement as they deem necessary, after which a resolution may assess the cost. The cost stated in the resolution shall constitute a lien on the property. The city clerk shall charge the assessments against the respective lots and parcels of land for municipal purposes. Thereafter, the amounts shall be collected at the same time and in the same manner as ordinary municipal assessments are collected, and shall be subject to the same penalties and the same procedure under foreclosure and sale in case of delinquency as provided for ordinary municipal assessments. 
(d)  The city clerk shall cause a certified copy of the resolution assessing the cost of abatement to be filed for recording in the office of the judge of probate and shall forward a copy to the county tax collector. Upon a filing, the tax collector shall add the amount of the lien to the ad valorem tax bill on the property and shall collect the amount as if it were a tax, using all methods available for collecting ad valorem tax, and remit the amount to the municipality. 
(Act 2012-440, p. 1241, §4.) 
Section 11-67-94 
Effect of redemption or sale. 
Where an assessment is made against a lot or lots or parcel or parcels of land, a subsequent redemption by a person authorized to redeem, or sale by the state, shall not operate to discharge, or in any manner affect the lien of the municipality for the assessment, but a redemptioner or purchaser at a sale by the state of any lot or lots, parcel or parcels of land upon which an assessment has been levied, whether prior to or subsequent to a sale to the state for the nonpayment of taxes, shall take the same subject to the assessment. 
(Act 2012-440, p. 1241, §5.) 
Section 11-67-95 
Construction of division. 
This division is cumulative in its nature and in addition to any and all power and authority which a municipality may have under any other law. 
(Act 2012-440, p. 1241, §6.) 
(Code 1956, §§ 11-12, 11-13, 11-68; Ord. No. 2736, § 56, 11-15-11; Ord. No. 2884, § 2, 8-5-14; Ord. No. 2990, § 6, 9-6-16) 
Cross reference- Occupant of dwelling unit responsible for extermination of pests on premises, § 5-174(307.5). 
Sec. 15-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2736, § 57, adopted Nov. 15, 2011, repealed § 15-18, which pertained to notices to abate and derived from Code 1956, § 11-69. 
Sec. 15-18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2736, § 58, adopted Nov. 15, 2011, repealed § 15-17, which pertained to abatements by the city, authorized, expenses, etc. and derived from Code 1956, §§ 11-68, 11-70; and Ord. No. 1331, § 1, adopted Aug. 15, 1989.

ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONED AND DILAPIDATED STRUCTURES 

Sec. 15-45 - Demolition of structures. 
    Demolitions of abandoned, dilapidated and unsafe structures shall be done using the procedures of the Code of Alabama 1975 Sections 11-40-30 through 11-40-36 listed below: 
    Section 11-40-30 
Demolition of unsafe structures. 
Any incorporated municipality of the state may, after notice as provided herein, move or demolish buildings and structures, or parts of buildings and structures, party walls, and foundations when found by the governing body of the municipality to be unsafe to the extent of being a public nuisance from any cause. 
(Acts 1989, No. 89-376, §1; Act 99-702, 2nd Sp. Sess., p. 216, §1.) 
    Section 11-40-31 
Notice from appropriate municipal officer of unsafe condition. 
The term "appropriate municipal official" as used in this article shall mean any municipal building official or deputy and any other municipal official or municipal employee designated by the mayor or other chief executive officer of the municipality as the person to exercise the authority and perform the duties delegated by this article. Whenever the appropriate municipal official of the municipality finds that any building, structure, part of building or structure, party wall, or foundation situated in the municipality is unsafe to the extent that it is a public nuisance, the official shall give the person or persons, firm, association, or corporation last assessing the property for state taxes and all mortgagees of record, by certified or registered mail to the address on file in the tax collector's or revenue commissioner's office, notice to remedy the unsafe or dangerous condition of the building or structure, or to demolish the same, within a reasonable time set out in the notice, which time shall not be less than 30 days or suffer the building or structure to be demolished by the municipality and the cost thereof assessed against the property. The mailing of the certified or registered mail notice, properly addressed and postage prepaid, shall constitute notice as required herein. Notice of the order, or a copy thereof, shall, within three days of the date of mailing, also be posted at or within three feet of an entrance to the building or structure. If there is no entrance, the notice may be posted at any location on the building or structure. 
(Acts 1989, No. 89-376, §2; Act 99-702, 2nd Sp. Sess., p. 216, §1.) 
    Section 11-40-32 
Hearing; appeal. 
(a)  Within the time specified in the notice, but not more than 30 days from the date the notice is given, any person, firm, or corporation having an interest in the building or structure may file a written request for a hearing before the governing body of the municipality, together with his or her objections to the finding by the municipal official that the building or structure is unsafe to the extent of becoming a public nuisance. The filing of the request shall hold in abeyance any action on the finding of the municipal official until determination thereon is made by the governing body. Upon holding the hearing, which hearing shall be held not less than five nor more than 30 days after the request, or in the event no hearing is timely requested, the governing body, after the expiration of 30 days from the date the notice is given, shall determine whether or not the building or structure is unsafe to the extent that it is a public nuisance. If it is determined by the governing body that the building or structure is unsafe to the extent that it is a public nuisance, the governing body shall order the building or structure to be demolished. The demolition may be accomplished by the municipality by the use of its own forces, or it may provide by contract for the demolition. The municipality may sell or otherwise dispose of salvaged materials resulting from the demolition. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the governing body at the hearing may, within 10 days thereafter, appeal to the circuit court upon filing with the clerk of the court notice of the appeal and bond for security of costs in the form and amount to be approved by the circuit clerk. Upon filing of the notice of appeal and approval of the bond, the clerk of the court shall serve a copy of the notice of appeal on the clerk of the municipality and the appeal shall be docketed in the court, and shall be a preferred case therein. The clerk of the municipality shall, upon receiving the notice, file with the clerk of the court a copy of the findings and determination of the governing body in its proceedings. Any trials shall be held without jury upon the determination of the governing body that the building or structure is unsafe to the extent that it is a public nuisance. 
(Acts 1989, No. 89-376, §3; Act 99-702, 2nd Sp. Sess., p. 216, §1.) 
    Section 11-40-33 
Costs of demolition. 
Upon demolition of the building or structure, the appropriate municipal official shall make a report to the governing body of the cost thereof, and the governing body shall adopt a resolution fixing the costs which it finds were reasonably incurred in the demolition and assessing the costs against the property. The proceeds of any moneys received from the sale of salvaged materials from the building or structure shall be used or applied against the cost of demolition. Any person, firm, or corporation having an interest in the property may be heard at the meeting as to any objection to the fixing of the costs or the amounts thereof. The municipal clerk of the municipality shall give notice of the meeting at which the fixing of the costs is to be considered by first-class mail to all entities having an interest in the property whose address and interest is determined from the tax collector's or revenue commissioner's records on the property or is otherwise known to the clerk. The fixing of the costs by the governing body shall constitute a special assessment against the lot or lots, parcel or parcels of land upon which the building or structure was located, and thus made and confirmed shall constitute a lien on the property for the amount of the assessment. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property except liens for taxes, and shall continue in force until paid. A certified copy of the resolution shall also be filed in the office of the judge of probate of the county in which the municipality is situated. Upon filing, the tax collector or revenue commissioner of the county shall add the amount of the lien to the ad valorem tax bill on the property and shall collect the amount as if it were a tax and remit the amount to the municipality. 
(Acts 1989, No. 89-376, §4; Act 99-702, 2nd Sp. Sess., p. 216, §1.) 
    Section 11-40-34 
Assessment of costs. 
The municipality may assess the costs authorized herein against any lot or lots, parcel or parcels of land purchased by the State of Alabama at any sale for the nonpayment of taxes, and where the assessment is made against the lot or lots, parcel or parcels of land, a subsequent redemption thereof by any person authorized to redeem, or sale thereof by the state, shall not operate to discharge, or in any manner affect the lien of the municipality for the assessment, but any redemptioner or purchaser at any sale by the state of any lot or lots, parcel or parcels of land upon which an assessment has been levied, whether prior to or subsequent to a sale to the state for the nonpayment of taxes, shall take the same subject to the assessment. The assessment shall then be added to the tax bill of the property, collected as a tax, and remitted to the municipality. 
(Acts 1989, No. 89-376, §5; Act 99-702, 2nd Sp. Sess., p. 216, §1.) 
    Section 11-40-35 
Payment of assessments. 
Payment of the assessment shall be made in the manner and as provided for the payment of municipal improvement assessments in Section 11-48-48, as the same has heretofore or may hereafter be amended. Any Class 2 municipality may use the provisions of Section 11-48-48.1 as the same has heretofore or may hereafter be amended. Upon the property owner's failure to pay the assessment the officer designated by the municipality to collect the assessments shall proceed to collect the assessment as provided in Sections 11-48-49 to 11-48-60, inclusive. The municipality may, in the latter notice, elect to have the tax collector or revenue commissioner collect the assessment by adding the assessment to the tax bill. Upon the election, the tax collector or revenue commissioner shall collect the assessment using all methods available for collecting ad valorem taxes. 
(Acts 1989, No. 89-376, § 6; Act 99-702, 2nd Sp. Sess., p. 216, § 1.) 
    Section 11-40-36 
Article cumulative. 
This article is cumulative in nature and is in addition to any power and authority which any municipality may have under any other law. 
(Acts 1989, No. 89-376, § 7; Act 99-702, 2nd Sp. Sess., p. 216, § 1.) 
(Ord. No. 2884, § 4, 8-5-14) 
Chapter 16 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, ETC.[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 12. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2096, § I, adopted Nov. 5, 2002, repealed former § 16-21 which pertained to uninvited soliciting upon private premises and derived from Code 1956, § 15-48. For similar provisions see §§ 16-21-16-31. 
Sec. 16-2. - Retailing merchandise from vehicles; prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle or other vehicle for the purpose of making retail sales of merchandise from such vehicle while so parked; and it shall be unlawful to make retail sales of any merchandise upon the sidewalks and in or upon the parkways running along or abutting upon any street except as allowed by the zoning ordinance of the city and after being duly licensed. 
(b)  However, this section shall not be construed to limit the right to park motor vehicles and other vehicles on the portions of the streets for the purpose of unloading merchandise sold at wholesale for delivery to duly licensed retail stores, nor to limit the right to park motor vehicles and other vehicles on the portions of the streets for any other purpose except the purpose of making retail sales of merchandise from such vehicles while so parked. 
(Code 1956, § 15-61) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21. 
Sec. 16-3. - Charitable solicitation within rights-of-way. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit for charitable, patriotic, philanthropic or other purposes in the right-of-way of any public street within the city. 
(b)  As used in this section, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
(1)  Charitable shall mean patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, religious, educational, civic or fraternal, either actual or purported. 
(2)  Persons shall mean any individual or natural person. 
(3)  Solicit and solicitation shall mean the request directly or indirectly of money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value will be used for a charitable or religious purpose as defined herein. These words shall also mean and include the following methods of securing money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or representation that it will be used for a charitable or religious purpose as herein defined: 
a.  Any oral or written request; 
b.  The distribution or distributing of any handbill, written advertisement or publications. 
(Ord. No. 1008, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-80) 
Cross reference- Charitable sidewalk sales, § 12-246; exemptions from registration, § 16-23. 
Secs. 16-4-16-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLICITATION REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2096, §§ II-XI, adopted Nov. 5, 2002, established provisions regulating solicitation. Said ordinance did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as Art. II, §§ 16-21-16-31, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 16-21. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Soliciting means any of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the sale or exchange of goods, wares, merchandise or perishables of any kind, for any kind of remuneration or consideration, regardless of whether advance payment is sought; 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers to apply for or to purchase insurance, publications or subscriptions to publications; 
(3)  Seeking to obtain contributions of any thing of value for the benefit of any individual, association, organization, corporation, or program; 
(4)  Seeking to obtain orders or prospective customers for goods or services; 
(5)  Requesting money or contributions of other goods or services for any charity or non-profit organization or for-profit organization or any other type or form of entity. 
    Solicitor means a person engaged in the activities defined by this article as soliciting. 
    Residence means any living unit contained within any building or structure that is occupied by any person as a dwelling consistent with the definition of "residence" as defined in the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Auburn. 
    Registrant or registered solicitor means any person who is subject to this article and who has obtained a valid certificate of registration from the City of Auburn, Alabama. 
    Charitable organization means any enterprise entered into with the primary purpose to pursue social, charitable or other benevolent activities and that is classified as a tax-exempt organization under applicable provisions of the United States Internal Revenue Code or the regulations thereunder. 
    Person means a natural person. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § II, 11-5-02) 
Sec. 16-22. - Registration requirements. 
(a)  Registration. All persons desiring to engage in soliciting at residences in the city shall apply to the city at a cost of seventy-five dollars ($75.00), paid in cash or cash equivalent, for a six-month certificate of registration. The applicant will provide, along with the solicitor's application, a criminal background history obtained from the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency, or any agency approved by the city manager or his designee, that has been obtained within the last ninety (90) days. The certificate of registration, executed by the city manager or his designee, shall be maintained by the city and a legible copy shall be worn by the registrant and visible at all times while soliciting. Upon request for inspection by an occupant of a residence or a police officer or city license and tax examiner, while the registered solicitor is transacting his or her business or seeking to transact his or her business at any residence, the registrant shall show his or her copy of the registration certificate. In addition to the registration fee, all other city ordinances levying business license fees and other license fees and taxes are applicable, including the business license ordinance requiring transient vendors to obtain a business license. 
(b)  Application for certificate . The city shall provide a standard form for use by solicitors for registration. The applicant for the registration certificate shall state in writing upon his or her oath or affirmation that the information is truthfully provided to the best of his or her knowledge and belief. The applicant shall supply with or upon the registration form the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's true, correct, and legal name and the name of the organization for which he or she will be soliciting. 
(2)  Address and phone number of applicant's home and applicant's place of business. 
(3)  Names and addresses of the corporate officers or the partners and the managers, if any of the entity for which the applicant will be soliciting. 
(4)  The purpose for which soliciting will be done. 
(5)  A brief description of the method of presentation that will be made. 
(6)  Whether a permit, license, or certificate of registration from any city in connection with soliciting has ever been revoked, explaining the circumstances. 
(7)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a misdemeanor or a felony. 
(8)  Documentation that the person is authorized to solicit for the organization. 
(9)  Two (2) passport sized photos taken within sixty (60) days of application. 
(c)  Non-endorsement . In addition, the applicant shall certify on the application form that if his or her registration is granted, he or she will not state, imply, or represent to any person that the issuance of the certificate is an endorsement by the city of the product, service, solicitor, or the organization represented by the solicitor. 
(d)  Proof of identification required . No certificate of registration shall be issued except upon proof of identification by the applicant in person providing one of the following, bearing a photograph of said applicant. 
(1)  A valid driver's license of any state in the United States. 
(2)  A valid United States Uniform Service Identification. 
(3)  A valid passport. 
(4)  A valid identification issued by any agency of a state for the purpose of identification of the holder. 
(e)  Registration complete with issuance . Registration shall be complete when the city issues the certificate of registration, which shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. 
(f)  Form of certificate . Each certificate shall be numbered, shall list the name of the individual solicitor and of all organizations on whose behalf he or she is authorized to solicit, the date on which the certificate will expire, and shall be dated and signed by the city manager or his designee. 
(g)  Maintenance of registry . The city shall maintain, available for public inspection during normal business hours, a record of every application received and acted upon, together with any information pertaining thereto, all certificates of registration issued, and all denials of applications. Each application shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and each certificate issued shall be assigned a number exclusive to the registrant. 
(h)  Renewal. Certificates shall be valid for a period of six (6) months from the date of issuance. Any certificate that has not been revoked may be renewed upon request of the registrant and upon payment of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) in cash or cash equivalent. The applicant shall be required to fill out a renewal application providing all information required in the initial registration application. 
(i)  Non-transferability . Certificates of registration shall be issued only in the name of the applicant and the firms, corporations or associations on whose behalf he or she is authorized to solicit. Each natural person soliciting must obtain a certificate of registration. Certificates shall be nontransferable. It shall be a violation for a solicitor whose certificate authorizes soliciting on behalf of a firm named in the certificate to solicit on behalf of any other firm, organization, or association or for any purpose other than that specified on the application. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § III, 11-5-02; Ord. No. 2855, § 1, 1-14-14; Ord. No. 2964, § 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 16-23. - Exemptions from registration. 
    The registration provisions of this article do not apply to the following: 
(1)  Persons making solicitations solely for a church, religious organization or charitable organization, including any unincorporated association or corporation under the supervision and control of any church, charitable organization or religious organization, if the church or organization is tax exempt under the provisions of the United States Internal Revenue Code. 
(2)  Students soliciting contributions to finance extracurricular academic, social, athletic, artistic, scientific or cultural programs, provided that the solicitation and its purpose have been approved by the principal, president or chief administrator of the school that the students attend and said approval has been filed in writing with the city. 
(3)  Persons canvassing for the purpose of distributing political literature or materials on behalf of a political party, candidate or public issue or introducing themselves as supporters of a candidate, political party, cause or issue. 
(4)  Persons making solicitations solely for a nationally recognized youth organization such as the YMCA, YWCA, scouting, or boys' and girls' clubs. 
    All other provisions of this article apply to those who qualify for an exemption. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § IV, 11-5-02) 
Cross reference- Charitable solicitation within rights-of-way, § 16-3. 
Sec. 16-24. - Deceptive soliciting practices prohibited. 
(a)  No solicitor or canvasser shall intentionally or recklessly make any materially false or fraudulent statement in the course of soliciting. 
(b)  No solicitor shall use a fictitious name, an alias, or any name other than his or her true, correct, and legal name. 
(c)  No solicitor shall represent, directly or by implication, that the city or any other governmental entity endorses the solicitation or that the granting of a certificate of registration implies any endorsement of the solicitor's product or service or of the individual solicitor. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § V, 11-5-02) 
Sec. 16-25. - No registration of felons. 
    No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of a federal or state felony. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § VI, 11-5-02) 
Sec. 16-26. - Revocation of certificate. 
    Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the city if registrant is convicted of a violation of the ordinance, if the registrant has falsified the application, if the city council declares so certificate revoked as provided for in section VII of this ordinance, or if the registrant otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration. Notice of revocation shall be immediately given to the registrant by personal service or by certified mail to the address listed on the application. Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of registration shall become null and void and shall remain so. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § VII, 11-5-02; Ord. No. 2855, § 3, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 16-27. - Appeal. 
    An applicant whose registration was denied or registrant whose certificate was revoked for any reason, other than by city council decision, shall have the right to appeal to the city manager. An applicant shall also have the right to appeal any adverse decision of the city manager to the city council. Any appeal must be demanded in writing sent by certified mail to the city manager within seven (7) calendar days of the decision that is being appealed. The written appeal shall sufficiently describe in detail the appealed action and the grounds of appeal. The right of appeal to the city council is not in derogation of any other rights in law or equity the applicant might have. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § VIII, 11-5-02; Ord. No. 2855, § 4, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 16-28. - Residential "no soliciting" notices. 
(a)  Any occupant of a residence or occupants of a multi-family dwelling who desire(s) not to have solicitors call on said residence(s) shall give notice of the desire to refuse solicitors by displaying a clearly visible weatherproof placard no smaller than sixteen (16) square inches and no larger than ninety-four (94) square inches stating "No Soliciting" which shall be posted on or near the main entrance of the private property and not within the public right-of-way. 
(b)  Residents of a residential subdivision may indicate their desire not to have solicitors call on any residences in that subdivision by giving notice of the desire to refuse solicitors by displaying a clearly visible weatherproof placard no smaller than sixteen (16) square inches and no larger than ninety-four (94) square inches stating "No Soliciting" which shall be posted on or near the main entrance of the subdivision on private property and not within the public right-of-way. 
(c)  The display of said placard shall be deemed to constitute notice to any solicitor that the inhabitant of the residence does not desire to invite solicitors. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § IX, 11-5-02; Ord. No. 2855, § 4, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 16-29. - Duties of solicitors. 
(a)  Every solicitor shall, upon entering premises on which a residence is located, examine the main entrance to the premises for any "No Soliciting" placards, and if one is posted, desist in any efforts to solicit or to leave any literature concerning the solicitation at that residence. Possession of a certificate of registration does not relieve any solicitor of this duty. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to appear at any private residence and canvass or solicit whereon a placard bearing the words "No Soliciting" indicating that solicitors are not wanted at such residence, is posted for public view, with the purpose of circumventing subsection 16-29(a) through ruse, deception, or concealment of a purpose to solicit or to take action calculated to secure an audience with the occupant of a residence that has a posted "No Soliciting" notice. Possession of a certificate of registration does not relieve any solicitor of this duty. 
(c)  Any solicitor who is asked to leave any residence by the occupant shall immediately and peacefully depart. Possession of a certificate of registration does not relieve any solicitor of this duty. 
(d)  Every solicitor shall at all times, while exercising the privilege in the City of Auburn incident to the permit, carry upon his person in plain sight, his permit and the same shall be visible about the body of said solicitor so as to be seen by any police officer or by any person who is solicited. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § X, 11-5-02; Ord. No. 2855, § 4, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 16-30. - Time of day restrictions on soliciting. 
    It is a violation of this article for any person, whether registered or not, to solicit any person at his or her residence before 8:00 a.m. All persons receiving a solicitor/door to door certificate shall only solicit during the following hours: 
September through May, 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 
June through August, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. 
Sundays, 12:00 noon-6:00 p.m. 
No door-to-door solicitation shall be conducted on holidays recognized by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § XI, 11-5-02; Ord. No. 2855, § 4, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 16-31. - Penalty for non-registration or violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of the article shall upon conviction be punished under the provision of Section 1-9 of The Code of the City of Auburn. 
(Ord. No. 2096, § XII, 11-5-02; Ord. No. 2855, § 4, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 16-32. - Suspension of certificate. 
(a)  Any certificate and/or solicitor license issued under this article may be suspended by written notice served on the registrant or oral notice to the registrant by the police chief or his/her designee or the revenue manager or his/her designee for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud or misrepresentation in the application of the certificate; 
(2)  Fraud or misrepresentation in the course of conducting solicitation activities; 
(3)  Conducting solicitation activities contrary to the conditions of the certificate; 
(4)  Conviction of any felony or crime involving dishonesty or false statement; or 
(5)  Conducting solicitation activities in such a manner as to create public nuisance or constitute danger to the public health, safety, and/or welfare. 
(b)  Upon suspension, the revenue department shall deliver written notice to the registrant stating the action taken and the reason supporting each action. The written notice shall be delivered to the local address set forth in the application. 
(c)  Solicitors whose certificates have been suspended may appeal the action by filing a written notice of appeal with the city manager. The appeal must be filed within ten (10) days of the notice of suspension. The city council shall hear and determine the appeal and the decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2855, § 2, 1-14-14) 
Secs. 16-33-16-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TICKET SCALPING REGISTRATION 

Sec. 16-51. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Ticket scalping means the act of offering for sale or selling admission tickets to events such as athletic events, concerts, movies, and other events or entertainments as itinerant, roving or transient vendors in public or private locations that have been previously sold or issued. This does not include the occasional sale of tickets purchased for personal use; not for the purpose of reselling tickets. 
    Ticket scalper means any person engaged in the activities of scalping tickets. This does not include a person who occasionally sells tickets which were originally purchased for personal use. 
    Person means natural person. 
    Permitted scalper means any person who is subject to this Ordinance and who has obtained a valid permit of registration from the City of Auburn. 
    Permit means the city issued photo identification card issued to every scalper registered with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2881, § II, 7-15-14) 
Sec. 16-52. - Registration requirement. 
(1)  Registration. Each person in the business of scalping admission tickets that have previously been sold or issued ("a resale" or "reselling") must apply with the City of Auburn's Revenue Office prior to making any such resale at a cost of one hundred fifty-five dollars ($155.00); paid by cash, cash equivalent, or credit card for a permit of registration. Permits are valid from July 1st of the current through June 30th of the following year. Each person scalping tickets must have a city issued scalping permit and picture identification (driver's license or state issued identification card) in their actual possession while reselling. The city issued scalping permit, executed by the city manager or his designee must be worn by the registrant so that it is fully visible at all times while engaged in the activity of scalping tickets in the city. 
(2)  Application for permit. The city shall provide a standard form for use by ticket scalpers for registering. The applicant for the permit shall state in writing upon his or her oath or affirmation that the information is truthfully provided to the best of his or her knowledge and belief. The applicant shall supply with or upon the registration form the following information: 
(a)  Applicant's true, correct, and legal name. 
(b)  Address and phone number of applicant's home and applicant's place of business if applicable. 
(c)  Two (2) passport sized photos taken within sixty (60) days of application. 
(3)  Non-endorsement. In addition, the applicant shall certify on the application form that if his or her registration is granted, he or she will not state, imply, or represent to any person that the issuance of the permit is an endorsement by the City of Auburn or Auburn University that the tickets being scalped are valid. 
(4)  Proof of identification required. No permit shall be issued except upon proof of identification by the applicant, in person, providing one of the following, bearing a photograph of said applicant: 
(a)  A valid driver's license of any state in the United States. 
(b)  A valid United States Uniform Service Identification. 
(c)  A valid identification issued by any agency of a state for the purpose of identification of the holder. 
(5)  Registration complete with issuance. Registration shall be complete when the city issues the permit of registration to scalp tickets, which shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. 
(6)  Form of permit registration. Each permit shall be uniquely numbered, shall list the name of the individual scalper, the date on which the permit will expire, and shall be dated and signed by the city manager or his designee. 
(7)  Maintenance of registry. The city shall maintain, and make available for public inspection during normal business hours, a record of every application received and acted upon, together with any information pertaining thereto, all permits issued and all denials of applications. Each application and each permit issued shall be assigned a number exclusive to the registrant. 
(8)  Renewal. Permits shall be valid from July 1st of the current year through June 30th of the following year. Any permit that has not been revoked may be renewed upon request of the registrant and upon payment of one hundred fifty-five dollars ($155.00) in cash, cash equivalent or credit card. The applicant shall be required to fill out a renewal application providing all information required in the initial registration application. Renewals will be sent to public safety for approval. 
(9)  Non-transferability. Permits of registration shall be issued only in the name of the applicant. The permit under this subsection shall be personal to the registrant, and accordingly each individual person making such a resale shall purchase a registration and no person may scalp tickets under a permit issued to another person. 
(Ord. No. 2881, § III, 7-15-14) 
Sec. 16-53. - Penalty. 
    Failure to register as a ticket scalper prior to ticket scalping shall be considered a violation of city ordinance and can be punishable in accordance with the provisions outlined in section 1-9 of the city code. Any person found scalping tickets without a valid scalping registration permit must immediately cease and desist all scalping activity until a valid registration permit has been obtained. 
(Ord. No. 2881, § IV, 7-15-14) 
Sec. 16-54. - Suspension of permit. 
    Any permit issued under this article may be suspended by issuance of a citation by any authorized sworn officer upon determination by the department of public safety personnel such as but not limited to: 
(a)  Falsifying application. 
(b)  Use of permit by someone other than the permitted scalper. 
(c)  Not having the permit and picture identification visible during ticket scalping activity. 
(d)  Conducting activity in such a manner as to create a public nuisance or constitute danger to the public health, safety, and/or welfare. 
(e)  Any other violation that public safety personnel deems necessary. 
    Suspension of permit shall require that the officer issue a written citation describing violation and registrant shall immediately surrender the previously issued permit. 
(Ord. No. 2881, § V, 7-15-14) 
Sec. 16-55. - Revocation of permit. 
    If permit holder is found guilty in municipal court of offense referenced in section 16-54, the municipal judge shall have sufficient grounds for revocation of the permit issued to the ticket scalper for the remainder of the season. 
(Ord. No. 2881, § VI, 7-15-14) 
Chapter 17 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Copies of the zoning ordinance and subdivision regulations in force in the city may be obtained from the city. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; drainage and flood control, Ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Municipal planning, Code of Ala., § 11-52-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 17-1-17-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 17-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a city planning commission. 
(Code 1956, § 2-3) 
State Law reference- Authority to create planning commission, Code of Ala., § 11-52-2. 
Sec. 17-17. - Members. 
    The city planning commission shall consist of nine (9) members appointed for term provided by statute in the manner provided by statute. 
(Code 1956, § 2-3) 
State Law reference- Membership of planning commission, Code of Ala., § 11-52-3. 
Sec. 17-18. - Conflict of interest. 
    No member of the city planning commission shall vote on any matter in which he or his spouse or dependents have a direct interest, nor shall a member vote in any matter involving a business with which he or his spouse or dependents have any direct interest or ownership. 
Sec. 17-19. - Master plan for city. 
(a)  The city planning commission is authorized and empowered to make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city, including any area outside its boundaries which, in the commission's judgment, bears relation to the planning of the city. Such plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive matter, shall show the commission's recommendations for the development of the territory including, among other things, the general location, character, and extent of streets, viaducts, subways, bridges, waterways, waterfronts, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds, squares, parks, aviation fields, and other public ways, grounds, and open spaces, the general location of public buildings and other public property, and the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, for water, light, sanitation, transportation, communications, power, and other purposes; also the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of any of the foregoing ways, grounds, open spaces, building, property, utilities, or terminals; as well as a zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location, and use of the buildings and premises. 
(b)  As the work of making the whole master plan progresses, the commission may from time to time adopt and publish a part or parts thereof, any such part to cover one or more major sections or divisions of the city or one or more of the aforesaid or other functional matters to be included in the said plan. The commission is hereby authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and do all things authorized to such commission by law, as it may deem necessary for its work. The commission is also authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and to do all things authorized to the commission by law, and to exercise such control as is authorized with reference to subdivision of unimproved property within five (5) miles of the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 2-4) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of planning commission, Code of Ala., §§ 11-52-8-11-52-10, 11-52-30(a). 
Sec. 17-20. - Appointments to the planning commission. 
    The city council of the City of Auburn hereby is authorized to approve the appointment of all members of the City of Auburn Planning Commission, except for the mayor or his designee, in lieu of appointment in the manner provided in Code of Ala. 1975 § 11-52-3, and hereby assumes the authority for approving the appointments to the planning commission under Act Number 2000-555. 
(Ord. No. 1919, § 1, 6-6-2000) 
Secs. 17-21-17-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOUSE NUMBERING AND STREET NAMES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21. 

Sec. 17-36. - Street naming and addressing policy established. 
    Specific addressing policy not referred to in this section can be found in the city's addressing and street naming manual. 
    All new street names shall be listed on the final subdivision plat for review by the city manager or his/her designee(s). New street names shall be unique in both written and spoken word and shall not have directional designations except in cases outlined below. Private streets shall be designated as so on a submitted subdivision plat. 
(Code 1956, § 18-17; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-37. - Changing an existing street name. 
    To change an existing street name, the applicant must send a written request to the planning department. The applicant may suggest an alternative name(s) that adhere to the same standards as above. The city shall notify all property owners on the street of the requested change by certified letter at the expense of the applicant. The proposed street name change shall be heard in a public hearing by the planning commission for recommendation to city council at the next scheduled meeting. If the name change is approved by city council, the street name shall officially be changed. 
(Code 1956, § 18-18; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-38. - Uniform numbering system established. 
    There is hereby established a uniform system for numbering buildings fronting on all streets, avenues, and public ways in the city and all houses and other buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code of 1956, § 18-19; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-39. - Baseline streets designated. 
(a)  East Magnolia Avenue, West Magnolia Avenue and extensions thereof shall constitute the baseline which will divide the city into northern and southern parts. All streets north of this baseline and running generally in a northerly-southerly direction shall be considered "north" streets, and likewise all streets south of this baseline and running generally in a northerly-southerly direction shall be considered "south" streets. 
(b)  North College Street, South College Street and extensions thereof shall be considered the baseline which will divide the city into eastern and western parts. Streets east of this baseline and running generally in an easterly-westerly direction shall be considered "east" streets and likewise streets west of this baseline and running generally in an easterly-westerly direction shall be considered "west" streets. 
(c)  Diagonal streets will be designated as "north," "south," "east" or "west" streets as deemed most appropriate in each case. 
(d)  Only streets that cross a baseline street shall have a directional prefix. For example, Dean Road shall be known as N. Dean Road north of Magnolia Avenue and S. Dean Road south of Magnolia Avenue. Glenn Avenue is known as E. Glenn Avenue east of College Street and W. Glenn Avenue west of College Street. 
(e)  Each building shall carry a number and address on the street which it faces as specified by the latest version of the International Fire Code. 
(Code 1956, § 18-19(1)-(4); Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-40. - Regulations for assigning numbers-How much frontage; odd and even. 
    The numbering of buildings on each street shall begin at the baseline. All numbers in residential areas shall be assigned on the basis of one number for each twenty-five (25) feet of frontage along the street. All numbers in business areas shall be assigned on the basis of seventeen and five-tenths (17.5) feet of frontage along the street for each number. Grid lines, as shown on the property numbering map which shall be on file in the office of the city manager, indicate the point at which numbers will change from one hundred to the next higher hundred. All buildings on the east of "north" streets, on the west of "south" streets, on the north of "west" streets and on the south of "east" streets shall bear even numbers. Likewise all buildings on the opposite sides of the streets shall bear odd numbers. 
(Code 1956, § 18-19(5); Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-41. - Same-In relation to building entrances. 
(a)  Buildings shall be assigned the number of the interval in which the main entrance falls. 
(b)  Where any building has more than one entrance serving separate occupants, a separate number shall be assigned to each entrance serving each occupant. 
(c)  Buildings having one main entrance only, serving separate occupants, shall be assigned one number only and separate units within such building shall carry a designation such as apartment, room, suite, etc., 1, 2, 3, etc., in addition to a number assigned to the main entrance. 
(d)  Buildings or groups of buildings having a greater number of entrances serving one or more occupants than intervals of street frontage shall be assigned one number as determined by the location of the major access from the street and separate units in the building or buildings shall carry a designation such as apartment, building, room, etc., 1, 2, 3, etc., in addition to the number assigned to the street entrance to the building or group of buildings. 
(Code 1956, § 18-20; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-42. - Same-Buildings outside continuously developed area. 
    Buildings located beyond the continuously developed area of the city where grid lines cannot be located to coincide with intersecting streets shall bear the hundred number determined by grid lines spaced approximately seven hundred (700) feet apart until such time as intermediate streets are located. Such grid lines shall be shown on the property numbering map. 
(Code 1956, § 18-21(1), (2); Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-43. - Numbers on streets not extending through to baseline. 
    All buildings facing streets not extending through to the baseline shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the street had extended to the baseline. 
(Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-44. - Size and placement of numbers. 
    Building numbers shall be provided for by the owner, occupant, or agent, and shall not be less than four (4) inches in height and shall be made of a durable and clearly visible material. The numbers shall be conspicuously placed immediately above, on or at the side of the proper door of each building so that the number can be seen plainly from the street at all times. Whenever any building is more than fifty (50) feet from the street line or where obstructions limit a clear view of the building from the street, numbers shall be near the walk, driveway or common entrance and upon a gatepost, fence, tree, post, or other appropriate place so as to be easily discernible from the street at all times. 
(Code 1956, § 18-22; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-45. - Numbering procedure on certain streets only. 
    On the East University Drive/Shug Jordan Parkway Loop/Bypass only, the following numbering procedures will be followed: 
(1)  On Shug Jordan Parkway only, beginning at the intersection of South College Street facing west and continuing to the intersection of North College Street, each twenty-five (25) feet of frontage will require a number, even numbers to the right, odd numbers to the left, continuously on this street beginning with the "100 series," with the number nearest the center of a lot being assigned to the lot. 
(2)  On East University Drive only, beginning at the intersection of South College Street facing east and continuing to the intersection of North College Street, numbers will be assigned to frontage on the basis of even numbers to the right, odd numbers to the left continuously on this street beginning with "0," with the number nearest the center of a lot being assigned to the lot. 
(Code 1956, § 18-23; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-46. - Property numbering map on file. 
    For the purpose of facilitating a correct numbering, a map of all streets, avenues, and public ways within the city showing the proper numbers of all buildings shall be kept on file in the office of the city manager. 
(Code 1956, § 18-24; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-47. - Information as to number assigned available from city manager. 
    It shall be the duty of the city manager or person designated by him/her to inform any party applying therefore of the number or numbers to be assigned to any property as provided in this article. 
(Code 1956, § 18-26; Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-48. - Assignment of number prerequisite for building permit; withholding final approval. 
    Whenever any building or structure shall be erected or located in the city, it shall be the duty of the owner to procure the correct number for same as provided in this article. No building permit shall be issued until the owner has procured the official number or numbers for the premises. Final approval of any structure erected, repaired, altered, or modified shall be withheld by the city building official until permanent and proper numbers have been affixed to the structure. 
(Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-49. - Addressing requirements. 
    The city manager or his/her designee is the legally mandated addressing authority for all addresses within the City of Auburn. In this role, structure and occupancy addresses are issued in the following categories: 
(1)  Address issuances for existing structures/occupancies. Occasionally, such as with new annexations, the address for an existing structure/occupancy may not be on file with the city. If research fails to reveal the in-use address, a valid address will be issued. 
(2)  Address issuances for temporary structures. Temporary structures such as sales and construction trailers normally require addresses for permitting and E-911 purposes. These addresses remain valid only as long as the temporary structure remains on the original property. 
(3)  Address changes at property owner's request. For personal or business reasons, the owner of a structure/occupancy may request a change of address. If the request is consistent with city policy, the city will consider the change and issue a new address when appropriate. 
(4)  Address changes initiated by the city. In order to resolve addressing discrepancies, the city will sometimes change one or more existing addresses. Property owners may appeal an address change to the city manager if they disagree with it. 
(5)  Temporary signage during new construction. Per the Auburn Fire Code, buildings under construction must have the building address conspicuously posted on the property visible from the street. The numbers shall be no less than four (4) inches in height. The address must either be on the building or on a temporary sign in front of the building. All new streets must have identifying signage temporarily posted until permanent signs can be constructed. 
(Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-50. - Private streets. 
    Establishment of private street. In the interest of public safety, property may be addressed off private streets at the discretion of the city manager and/or his/her designee. All lots must meet minimum frontage requirements on a public right-of-way as outlined in the City of Auburn Subdivision Regulations. Private streets shall have all traffic control features such as striping, signage, etc. in conformance with standards established by the public works manual. 
(a)  Naming a private street. All private streets must have a name that meets city street naming regulations outlined in this article. The name shall be unique in spoken and written word to avoid confusion for emergency services should the need arise. 
(b)  Addressing off a private street. When deemed appropriate by the city manager and/or his/her designee, addresses shall be assigned using the same standards as public streets outlined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Sec. 17-51. - Comprehensive street naming plan. 
    For the purpose of clarifying and systematizing the present street naming pattern in the city and to implement the application of matters set forth in previous sections, the city planning commission is hereby authorized to prepare and present to the governing body a complete plan for the naming of all streets, avenues, and public ways within the city. Whenever additional territory shall be annexed to the city, the commission shall extend such plan to include such territory and present same to the governing body. The city planning commission shall follow all rules as set forth in this article. The commission, if it sees fit, may hold public hearings at which interested property owners may express their views concerning the changing of the name of any street, avenue or public way. 
(Ord. No. 2694, § 1, 2-1-11) 
Secs. 17-52-17-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MUNICIPAL TREE ORDINANCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1875, adopted Nov. 16, 1999, amended Art. IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. IV was comprised of §§ 17-61-17-66, and derived from Ord. No. 1269, adopted Jan. 19, 1988; and Ord. No. 1339, adopted Oct. 16, 1989. 
Cross reference- Tree commission, § 2-111 et seq.; drainage and flood control, § 7-1 et seq.; streets and sidewalks, § 21-1 et seq. 

Sec. 17-61. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the Municipal Tree Ordinance of the City of Auburn, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-62. - Value of urban trees. 
    Trees are recognized as a valid asset providing a more healthful and beautiful environment in which to live, providing oxygen, shade, aesthetics, and a priceless psychological counterpoint to the urban setting. Trees are economically beneficial in attracting new industry and residents by enhancing the value and marketability of property and promoting the stability of desirable neighborhoods. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-63. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, words and their derivations shall have the following meanings given herein: 
(1)  City official: Person or persons designated by the city manager to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Park: A tract of land set aside for public use and owned by the City of Auburn. 
(3)  Protective measures: Any steps taken to safeguard the appearance, health, condition, or continued viability of a protected tree. Typical examples are: physical structures limiting access to a protected tree, pruning to allow access to a site, supplemental watering or fertilization, washing of canopy to remove dust or other residues, berms or grading to prevent erosion or silting in a protected root zone, signage indicating protected status of trees or other methods as deemed necessary at time of permitting. 
(4)  Protected tree: Any tree located on public property within the City of Auburn. 
(5)  Public property: Any right-of-way, park, or other ground owned by the City of Auburn. 
(6)  Replacement tree(s): Trees required to be planted as compensation for the removal of viable, non-hazard trees. 
(7)  Tree: A woody plant which at maturity is thirteen (13) feet or more in height with a single trunk at least three (3) inches in diameter, unbranched for at least several feet above the ground and having a more or less definite crown. 
(8)  Tree commission: Composed of members appointed per City Ordinance Nos. 1170 and 1172 (Code section 2-111 et seq.), plus the beautification and urban forestry supervisor. 
(9)  Tree trust: The National Tree Trust is a public foundation created through a one-time appropriation from Congress. Other funding comes from outside sources, mainly gifts and donations. It is the purpose of the Tree Trust to plant and/or preserve as many trees as possible on public land through volunteerism. 
(10)  Tree maintenance: Measures performed to promote the desirable growth and health of a tree such as, but not limited to, watering, fertilizing, mulching, weeding, pest management, and physical protection. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-64. - Tree maintenance and protection. 
(1)  City departments shall seek the counsel and recommendations of the city official prior to the removal and/or alteration of any tree on public property or right-of-way unless the tree(s) poses immediate danger to the public. 
(2)  The city official may cause to be removed any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or is infested with any disease, injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(3)  Trees severely damaged by storms or other natural causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical, may be exempted from this article. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person, business or other entity, without first obtaining a permit as herein provided, to remove, cause to be removed, relocate, alter, damage or destroy any tree on public property, including public rights-of-way. 
(5)  No person shall engage in the pruning or topping of trees on any public property except in conformance with the most current practices of the International Society of Arboriculture, the National Arborist Association Standards, and the National Electric Safety Code. 
(6)  No new curb cuts, which shall endanger protected trees, shall be allowed without the express permission of the city. 
(7)  To protect the longevity of protected trees, the appropriate city departments shall review all applications for construction permits, including clearing and grading permits. Protective measures may be prescribed by the city to safeguard the health, appearance, condition and viability of protected trees. The cost and responsibility for implementing and maintaining all prescribed protective measures shall be born solely by the applicant. Any deviation from the measures prescribed by the city to protect said trees shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-65. - Permit for removal, relocation or alteration of trees on public property. 
    Application shall be made to the appropriate city department for the removal, relocation or alteration of any protected tree. When reviewing applications, the city shall consider the following criteria: 
(1)  The condition of the tree(s) identified in the application and that of the trees in the immediate proximity with respect to health, structural integrity, potential hazard, location to existing and proposed structures, paving, and utilities. 
(2)  The absolute necessity of the removal, relocation or alteration for the reasonable use of the property. 
(3)  The impact upon the area tree canopy of the proposed removal, relocation or alteration. 
(4)  The applicant's consent to abide by all specified protection and replacement measures. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-66. - Replacement of trees and planting of new trees on or near public property. 
(1)  Should permission be granted for the removal of any protected tree(s), the applicant shall bear the responsibility and full cost for the replacement of said tree(s). 
(2)  The city shall specify the species, planting time and planting location of all replacement trees, along with any additional conditions or protective measurers to be implemented by the applicant. 
(3)  Under no circumstances shall new trees be planted within ten (10) feet of utilities, curbs, gutters, and sidewalks on city right-of-ways unless otherwise approved by the city. 
(4)  Should any replacement tree die or substantially decline, in the opinion of the city official, within a period of two (2) years after planting, the responsibility for replacement of said tree shall be solely that of the original applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-67. - Operation and duties of the tree commission. 
    The tree commission shall conduct regular monthly meetings and other called meetings as needed. It shall make its own rules of order, keep records of its proceedings, and annually elect from its voting members a chairman, vice-chairman, secretary, and treasurer and such other officers as it may need. A majority of its voting members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
    The tree commission may: 
(a)  Increase public awareness of and develop public support for tree preservation. 
(b)  Cooperate and coordinate its activities with the city staff and city council in the protection, maintenance, planning, planting, and removal of trees on public lands. 
(c)  Increase urban tree inventory through annual recommendations of appropriate trees along streets, in parks, and other public places. 
(d)  Identify, and recommend removal of dead, dying, diseased, or insect-infested trees on public property. 
(e)  Encourage the preservation of trees by developers and landowners. 
(f)  Plan and coordinate an annual Arbor Week observance. 
(g)  Inventory the city's tree population, determine needs, and periodically prepare a city tree plan. 
(h)  Report annually to the city council, summarizing goals, projects, and expenses. 
(i)  Solicit and expend Auburn Tree Trust funds for the purpose of increasing tree inventory. 
(j)  Promote standards of tree maintenance to foster the tree population. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-68. - Policies and procedures. 
    Policies and procedures for carrying out the provisions of this article are set out in The Municipal Tree Ordinance Implementation Guidelines, a copy of which shall be on file with the city official and available to all city departments, which guidelines may be amended from time to time by the city council of the City of Auburn. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-69. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article or The Municipal Tree Ordinance Implementation Guidelines shall upon conviction, be punished under the provisions of section 1-9 of the Code of the City of Auburn. 
    In addition, the municipal judge shall have the authority to require those convicted of violating any provisions of this article or The Municipal Tree Ordinance Implementation Guidelines to replace trees damaged or destroyed. The judge shall consider the recommendations of the beautification and urban forestry superintendent regarding the species and sizes of replacement trees. 
(Ord. No. 1875, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Chapter 18 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police department to enforce certain dog control provisions, § 4-20; fire department, § 9-16 et seq.; registration of secondhand dealers with police, § 12-204; transcript of secondhand dealer's daily register to go to police, § 12-206; police officers authorized to use firearms in performance of duties, § 13-4; police directing traffic, § 22-6. 
State Law reference- Authority to establish police force, Code of Ala., § 11-43-55. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definition of "police chief." 
    Wherever used in this chapter, the following title shall have the meaning hereinafter ascribed: "Chief of police" means the chief law enforcement officer of the city and his successors in office. 
(Code 1956, § 16-1) 
Sec. 18-2. - Enforcement of state law. 
    The chief of police or any policeman of the city has authority and it is his duty to make arrests for offenses against the laws of the state in all cases where such authority is now or shall hereafter be conferred on such officers by the laws of the state, and in making such arrests, whether with or without a warrant, he shall have all the authority conferred, and be subject to all the duties imposed upon such officers by the laws of the state in existence now or that may hereafter be enacted. 
(Code 1956, § 16-4) 
Cross reference- Adoption of state statutes and rules on alcoholic beverages, § 3-4; adoption of state offenses, § 13-1. 
Sec. 18-3. - Enforcement of city ordinances. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and that of the police force to enforce the ordinances of the city and all of the penal laws of the state in the city, and police jurisdiction thereof, to arrest all persons violating either of the same, such arrests to be made as elsewhere provided for in this Code. When required by law, he shall carry such persons so arrested before the municipal judge for examination or trial for the violation of a state law, or for trial for the violation of an ordinance of the city or of any provision of this Code. 
(Code 1956, § 16-5) 
Cross reference- Municipal court, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 18-4. - Performance of duties by chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall perform such other duties as may be imposed upon him by the statutes of the state or the laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 16-10) 
Cross reference- Parade permits issued by chief of police, § 21-113; chief of police has authority to provide for bus stops, loading zones, etc., § 22-56. 
Sec. 18-5. - Abandoned and stolen personal property. 
(a)  Storage. The chief of police and the officers serving under his direction are hereby authorized and empowered to take up and store any and all abandoned or stolen personal property found within the corporate limits of the city and within the police jurisdiction thereof. 
(b)  Records. The chief of police shall establish and maintain a permanent record of all abandoned or stolen personal property coming into his hands under the provisions of this section. This record shall show the date of the taking of each piece of such property, the place where found and taken, and a description of each piece of such property. 
(c)  Sales. At least every six (6) months the chief of police shall sell at public auction to the highest bidder for cash the property which shall have then been taken up and stored for a period of three (3) months or more, the sales to be made after notice of the time and place thereof shall have first been given by publication of notice once a week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation published in the city. The first publication shall be at least twenty (20) days before the sale. The owner of any property taken up and stored may redeem the same at any time prior to its sale by paying the reasonable expense of taking the property in charge, its maintenance and storage and a pro rata of the cost of publication. Each article shall be sold separately and a notation in the storage record book shall be made of the amount received for each article. The person making the sale shall have the right to reject any and all bids if the amount bid is unreasonably low, and shall have the right to continue the sales from time to time if no bidders are present. After deducting and paying all expenses incurred in the taking up, storing, maintaining and selling of the property, the balance, if any, shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1956, §§ 16-13-16-15) 
Cross reference- Wrecked, damaged, demolished motor vehicles, § 15-36; cars towed for parking violations subject to provisions of Code section 18-5, § 22-29. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 11-47-116. 
Secs. 18-6-18-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE 

Sec. 18-16. - Authorization; size of force. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized to form an auxiliary police force for the city. He shall appoint, subject to the approval of the city manager, such persons to the force as he deems necessary, with a maximum of fifty (50) members. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 1, 12-2-75) 
Sec. 18-17. - Eligibility for membership. 
    To be eligible for appointment to the auxiliary police force a person must be of good character, over twenty-one (21) years of age, a resident of the county, and willing to serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 1, 12-2-75) 
Sec. 18-18. - Appointment. 
    Appointment as a member of the auxiliary police force shall be for a period of one year at a time, and such appointment shall be at the pleasure of the chief of police who may terminate such appointment by giving the member written notice of termination of membership, or such appointment will terminate upon repeal of this article. Members of the auxiliary police force may resign membership by written notice to the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 5, 12-2-75) 
Sec. 18-19. - Oath. 
    Upon appointment as a member of the auxiliary police force, each person, upon accepting membership therein shall take the same oath that is required of the regular police officers of the city. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 2, 12-2-75) 
Sec. 18-20. - Duties. 
    The members of the auxiliary police force shall perform such duties and at such times as the chief of police shall prescribe, and shall be governed by the rules and regulations of the police department, and special rules pertaining to the auxiliary police force. Service as a member of the auxiliary police force shall be voluntary and without pay. Each member of the force during his tour of duty shall have the right to carry a gun upon his person, to assist regular officers in making arrests and serving warrants and otherwise to conduct himself as a regular police officer. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 2, 12-2-75) 
Sec. 18-21. - Uniform and equipment. 
    Members of the auxiliary police force shall perform their duties in a police uniform or other clothing approved by the chief of police, and members may be furnished with a standard service revolver if such is excess to the department, but each of them shall be furnished with a badge, cap piece, shoulder patch, and identification card signed by the chief of police when such member is sworn in. Such badge and card shall be carried by each member of the auxiliary police force whenever he is on duty and shall be surrendered to the chief of police at any time the chief requests the surrender of the badge, cap piece, shoulder patch, identification card, and other such equipment as might be issued. Equipment issued shall not be deemed expendable, and accountability for all property issued under the provisions of this article shall be the responsibility of the chief of police or his designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 4, 12-2-75) 
Sec. 18-22. - Special rules. 
    The chief of police with written approval of the city manager shall promulgate, in writing, special rules pertaining to the auxiliary police force, in addition to the regular rules and regulations of the police department. These special rules shall define, but not be limited to, the following items: Entrance requirements, limit of authority, chain of command, training, specific duties authorized, required service time, insurance requirements, testing, signed release for liability by city for personal injury while on or off duty, statement of fact pertaining to uniforms and equipment and requirement for such, and other such requirements as may be deemed necessary by the chief of police for the operation and control of the police auxiliary force. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 3, 12-2-75) 
Sec. 18-23. - Funding. 
    Only funds that are appropriated in the general fund budget by line item and designated "auxiliary police force" may be expended for the purpose of establishing and maintaining an auxiliary police force. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 6, 12-2-75) 
Chapter 19 - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing, § 5-213 et seq.; drainage and flood control, Ch. 7. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 19-1-19-12. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 19-13-19-20. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 19-21. - Construction permit and plans, etc. 
(a)  No person shall lay or construct any sanitary sewer within the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city engineer.
