(Ord. No. 1810, § 1, 1-19-99; Ord. No. 2247, § 19, 9-21-04; Ord. No. 2507, § 14, 8-21-07; Ord. No. 2514, § 15, 9-18-07; Ord. No. 2588, § 1, 1-20-09; Ord. No. 2619, §§ 16, 18, 9-1-10; Ord. No. 2838, § 1, 8-6-13; Ord. No. 2989, § 2, 8-16-16; Ord. No. 3072, § 1, 1-2-18) 
Sec. 19-154. - Adjustment for unusual usage/or inaccurate meter readings. 
    The city manager or his designated representative may authorize the water works board to adjust the charges for sewer service in cases in which it is clear and evident that water usage as reflected by a monthly meter reading is not indicative of the amount of waste water which entered the sanitary sewer due to an unusual circumstance, such as a water line leak. In cases in which the city manager or his designated representative determines that a water user regularly uses water that does not enter the sanitary sewer as waste water, and if such use is metered separately from any water which does enter the sanitary sewer as waste water, then said usage shall not be subject to the sewer service charge. 
(Ord. No. 1810, § 1, 1-19-99) 
Sec. 19-155. - Additional charges for discharges placing unusual burden on system authorized. 
    In cases where the character or volume of sewage from any premises is such that it may impose an unusual burden upon the sanitary sewer system, the city may impose a surcharge or fee based on other strength, volume or constituents for such service to and for such premises, or may, in lieu of such additional charges, require such sewage to be treated in a manner specified by the city before being discharged into the sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 1810, § 1, 1-19-99) 
Sec. 19-156. - Late fee. 
    The city council hereby ratifies and confirms the establishment of a minimum late fee of five dollars ($5.00) on bills for city utility services, which include sanitary sewer services and garbage collection services, by the Water Works Board of the City of Auburn (the water board), which manages the billing and collection for water, sanitary sewer and garbage collection services provided within the city. Further provided, the council does authorize the water board, under the auspices of the management agreement between the city and the board which was authorized by council Resolution 83-65, to set the amount of late fees and to establish the policies regarding the billing and collection of late fees for the city's sanitary sewer and garbage college services. 
(Ord. No. 1810, § 1, 1-19-99; Ord. No. 1929, § 1, 6-20-00; Ord. No. 2619, § 17, 9-1-10; Ord. No. 2706, § 1, 5-17-11) 
Sec. 19-157. - Billing and payments. 
    The rates and charges herein provided for shall be payable beginning with the first date of service. The obligation to pay such bill shall be that of the party who requested said service to be provided to the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1810, § 1, 1-19-99) 
Secs. 19-158, 19-159. - Reserved. 
Sec. 19-160. - Past due bills. 
(a)  Any customer failing or refusing to pay his or her sewer service charges in full within twenty-one (21) days after the rendition thereof shall be denied the use of the sewer services and facilities afforded by the sanitary sewer system of the city and his or her deposit may be applied in payment of the unpaid balance of his bill. In this case, sewer services shall be discontinued until such time as all past-due charges as well as a water reconnection charge for each reconnection are paid. If service has been discontinued and the deposit applied to the account balance, a new deposit shall be paid. These charges shall be in addition to the late fee of ten (10) per cent provided for herein. 
(b)  The water works board of the city shall, as an agent of the city, shut off the water service of any of its customers for failure to pay sanitary sewer service charges within twenty-one (21) days after the same shall have become due and payable. 
(Ord. No. 1810, § 1, 1-19-99) 
Sec. 19-161. - Unpaid bills. 
    In the event that any sanitary sewer service charge is not paid within sixty (60) days after it is due and payable, it shall be the mandatory duty of the city manager to cause appropriate action to be initiated and concluded to collect such charge from the party who requested that said services be provided to the premises. The reasonable expenses incurred by the city in collecting or attempting to collect such charge shall be an additional obligation of the occupant of the premises and shall be added to the amount of and become a part of any judgement against any such party. 
(Ord. No. 1810, § 1, 1-19-99) 
Secs. 19-162-19-174. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS FOR PRIVATE LIFT STATIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1345, adopted Feb. 6, 1990, was not enacted as a specific addition or amendment to the Code; hence, codification of §§ 1-5 thereof as a new Art. V, §§ 19-175-19-179, of Ch. 19 has been at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; planning and development, Ch. 17. 

Sec. 19-175. - Construction of new lift stations. 
    Complete engineering plans in accordance with recognized Water Pollution Control Federation design standards shall be submitted for review to the city's engineering department for any proposed private lift stations. In the event such engineering plans are approved and such private lift station is completed, upon completion of the private lift station, complete "as-built" drawings, including copies and specifications of all equipment, submittals and certified test results of the installation, shall be submitted to the engineering department and approved by said department prior to allowing the system to be utilized for domestic or industrial waste water flows. 
(Ord. No. 1345, § 1, 2-6-90) 
Sec. 19-176. - Inspection. 
    All private lift stations shall be inspected at least semiannually by the city engineer or his duly authorized representative to ensure that the lift station is performing as designed. Prior to the inspection, the city shall notify the designated representative of the owner of the private lift station of said inspection at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the inspection. The inspection will be made to determine the condition of the station and the manner in which it is being operated and maintained. Such inspection will include, but may not be limited to, those items shown on an inspection sheet, marked Exhibit "A," attached to and made a part of the original ordinance from which this article was derived, which ordinance is on file for public inspection in the office of the city clerk. Any defects or problems discovered by the city shall be furnished to the owner of the lift station and the defects or problems shall be corrected within ten (10) days. In the event the problems or defects are not timely corrected, the owner of the private lift station shall be subject to the fines set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 1345, § 2, 2-6-90) 
Sec. 19-177. - Additional information to be furnished to city. 
    The owner of any private lift station shall submit and maintain current telephone numbers and addresses for the plant manager or project manager for each development served by any private lift station within the City of Auburn. The owner shall further submit and keep current the names, addresses and telephone numbers of those persons responsible for routine maintenance and operation of the private lift station. 
(Ord. No. 1345, § 3, 2-6-90) 
Sec. 19-178. - Notice to city of any malfunctions. 
    In the event a private lift station shall malfunction for any reason, whether for power outage or mechanical failure, the owner of the private lift station shall immediately notify the engineering department of the city of the malfunction and the cause of the problem and the proposed action to be taken to correct the malfunction or problem. In the event that the malfunction or power outage is not caused by a natural disaster, said malfunction or problem shall be corrected no longer than twenty-four (24) hours after the initial malfunction or problem occurs. Each 24-hour period or portion thereof subsequent to the initial 24-hour period that said malfunction or problem is not corrected shall be deemed a separate violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1345, § 4, 2-6-90) 
Sec. 19-179. - Existing lift stations. 
    The city shall notify in writing the current owners of all existing private lift stations within the city of the passage of the ordinance from which this article is derived and said owners shall have sixty (60) days from said notice to submit an engineering report detailing the current condition of the private lift station and certification that the station is adequate to handle the development that the station currently serves. Any station deemed not adequate shall be given six (6) months from the date of said notice to modify and construct additions to the stations to ensure that said stations shall be adequate. During the modification or construction, periodic inspections shall be conducted by the city. In addition, prior to beginning any modification or construction, the owner of the private lift station shall submit to the city the engineering plans and specifications required under section 19-175 above. Each day that the owner fails to timely comply with this section shall be deemed a separate violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1345, § 5, 2-6-90) 
Chapter 20 - SOLID WASTES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 15; garbage not to be deposited on public or private property in unsanitary manner, § 19-60. 
State Law reference- Solid Wastes Disposal Act, Code of Ala., § 22-27-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms when used in this chapter shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
    Cart shall mean a watertight receptacle or container of substantial construction made of reinforced or rib plastic having a holding capacity of not less than sixty-four (64) gallons, unless approved by the solid waste director, and equipped with a tight-fitting lid or cover and with one or more handles by which the same may be conveniently lifted or moved; provided, however, the container is authorized by the solid waste department and approved as suitable for pickup and dumping by hydraulic lift or hoist. 
    Construction/demolition landfill (CID) shall mean a discrete area of land or an excavation that receives construction/demolition waste, and/or rubbish, that is not a land application unit, surface impoundment, injection well, or waste pile. 
    Construction materials shall mean material delivered, generated or excavated during construction practices including, but not limited to, debris from construction materials, concrete, lumber, stumps and limbs. 
    Curbside shall mean that area in front of the house immediately behind the curb of the street; and where there is no curb and gutter, that area in front of the house nearest and most convenient to the traveled portion of the street, the use of which will not block, hinder or obstruct, vehicular or other traffic lawfully using the street. Where alleys provide access suitable for garbage pickup, the words "curbside" shall also mean that area in the rear of the house most convenient to the traveled portion of the alley, the use of which will not block, hinder or obstruct vehicular or other traffic lawfully using the alley. 
    Garbage customer shall mean tenant, lessee, occupant, or owner of a premise which receives solid waste services from the city as provided herein. 
    Refuse shall mean both garbage and trash as defined herein, dead animals, and any other material or substance, regardless of definition, presently picked up and handled by the solid waste department of the city, except oversized burnables and oversized nonburnable wastes. 
    Sanitary landfill shall mean a controlled area of land upon which solid waste is deposited, and is compacted and covered with compacted earth each day as deposited, with no on-site burning of ashes, and so located, contoured and drained that it will not constitute a source of water pollution as determined by the water division of the Alabama department of environmental management. 
    Solid waste department shall mean the city solid waste department and/or refuse collection and disposal supervised by the city solid waste department. 
    Solid waste officer shall mean the city manager or his designated agent. 
    Trash shall mean any refuse other than garbage or putrescible material. It shall include discarded flower decoration, shrubbery trimmings, old furniture, appliances, straw, grass clippings, weeds, fallen leaves, vines, branches and limbs of a maximum five (5) feet in length and/or four (4) inches in diameter, except as herein otherwise provided. 
(Code 1956, § 11-1; Ord. No. 1077, § 1, 4-20-82; Ord. No. 1658, § 1, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 1668, § 1, 9-17-96) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 22-27-2. 
Sec. 20-2. - Use of garbage cans or other containers for disposal of garbage, refuse, etc. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person in possession, charge or control, jointly or severally, of any premises where garbage, nonputrescible wastes, or refuse is created or accumulated, and in case of multiple dwellings or multiple occupancy, the owner, agent or occupant, jointly or severally, of the premises, at all times to keep or cause to be kept a sufficient number of garbage cans or other containers (at least one for each family or other single dwelling unit) for the deposit therein. Lids or covers of such garbage cans or other containers shall be kept tightly closed at all times other than when garbage or refuse is being deposited therein or removed therefrom. 
(b)  Containers used for the deposit of garbage for collection by or supervised by the solid waste department shall be in good condition so that collection therefrom shall not injure the person collecting the contents thereof. Containers having ragged or sharp edges or other defects must be promptly replaced upon receipt of notice from the solid waste department and if not so replaced within ten (10) days of receipt of such notice, such nonconforming or defective container may be collected by or the collection thereof supervised by the solid waste department, and disposed of as waste and every person in possession, charge, or control, and in the event of multiple occupancy, the owner, or agent, or occupant of the premises, jointly or severally, shall be held responsible. 
(c)  Business establishments or multiple occupancy dwellings where such units produce three (3) cubic yards of refuse per week shall arrange for the garbage or refuse to be deposited in large removal containers. Business establishments or multiple dwellings or multiple occupancy where such units produce less than three (3) cubic yards of refuse per week, shall use carts provided by the city unless alternative arrangements have been made by agreement with the director of solid waste. 
(d)  No hazardous material/waste shall be placed in a garbage container. Hazardous material/waste is a substance in quantity and form which may pose an unreasonable risk to health and safety or property. Ashes from the fireplace or from front yard burnings shall not be placed in any container. Broken glass, sharp metal objects or hypodermic needles shall not be placed in plastic bags, but instead placed in a sealed container. 
(Code 1956, §§ 11-3, 11-7; Ord. No. 1658, § 2, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-3. - Unkept premises declared a nuisance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in possession, charge of or control of any premises to keep, cause to be kept or allow the keeping on any premises within the corporate limits of the city garbage, trash or rubbish, in such manner that it will become offensive or deleterious to health or likely to cause disease and the same is hereby declared a public nuisance. The health officer of the county, his authorized representatives and/or the solid waste officer are hereby authorized to inspect any premises in the city for the purpose of seeing that the requirements of this chapter are being complied with and it shall be unlawful for any person to resist or interfere with such representatives by word, deed or act in the performance of such inspection. 
(Code 1956, § 11-10; Ord. No. 1658, § 3, 9-3-96) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 15. 
Sec. 20-4. - Littering. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or business, to sweep, throw or otherwise deposit or cause to be swept, thrown or otherwise deposited any construction materials, dirt, earth, rock, clay, sand, debris, garbage or rubbish into or on any public street, alley, sidewalk, park or the property of another person or property which is in the possession of another person within the corporate limits of the city or to permit any dirt, earth, rock, clay, sand, debris, garbage or refuse to accumulate in such manner that it may be carried and deposited into or on any of the above places by action of the rain, wind or snow. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or business to sweep, throw or deposit or cause to be swept, thrown or deposited into or on any canal, stream, public water drain, sewer or receiving basin within the corporate limits of the city any construction materials, dirt, rock, clay, sand, debris, earth, garbage or refuse or to permit same to accumulate in such a manner that it may be carried and deposited into or on any of the above by action of the rain, wind or snow. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any firm or business house to permit the residue from their sweeping of buildings, parking areas or sidewalks to be swept into curb lines or street but shall have the residue or trash placed in proper receptacles for pickup by garbage crews. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or business to throw, cast, or otherwise deposit or cause to be thrown, cast or otherwise deposit any construction materials, dirt, earth, rock, clay, sand, debris, paper, garbage, refuse containers, either glass, metal or paper, or any other substance of any kind in or upon any curb, gutter, street, avenue, highway, sidewalk, park, parkway, or lot, vacant or occupied. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw litter or allow litter to be thrown from a motor vehicle onto or upon any highway, road, street or any public right-of-way. Violation of this provision shall raise a prima facie presumption that the driver or operator of the motor vehicle committed or permitted the violation and the burden of proof shall be upon the driver to show otherwise. 
(f)  Any person convicted of a violation of the provisions as set forth in paragraphs (a), (b), (c), and/or (d) of this section shall be guilty of an offense against the city and shall be punished as provided for in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(g)  Any person found to be in violation of the provisions as set forth in paragraph (e) of this section shall be guilty of an offense against the city and shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  For a first violation: A fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(2)  For a second violation: A fine of not less than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00). 
(3)  For a third or any subsequent violation: A fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment of not more than ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, at the discretion of the municipal judge trying the case. 
(Code 1956, § 11-11.3; Ord. No. 1404, § 1, 12-17-91) 
Cross reference- Unlawful to place garbage or objectionable waste on public or private property, § 19-60. 
Sec. 20-5. - Public trash receptacles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or cause to be removed from any street or sidewalk in the city any receptacle furnished by the city for the deposit of trash. It shall be unlawful for any person to sit upon or deface any such receptacle or to cause it to be used in any way which will make it inaccessible for the receipt of trash. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, store or cause to be placed or stored any goods, merchandise, lumber, trash or any other material near any such receptacle in such manner as to interfere with or preclude the use of any such receptacle for the purpose which it is intended to serve. 
(Code 1956, § 11-11.7) 
Sec. 20-6. - Scavenging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any garbage or other like material from any garbage can or other container within the corporate limits of the city after it has been placed therein except for the owner or under the orders of an officer, agent or employee of the solid waste department. 
(Code 1956, § 11-11.4; Ord. No. 1658, § 4, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-7. - Drive-in establishments. 
    The owners, operators, lessees, and employees of any soda fountain, lunch counter, drugstore, grocery or other mercantile establishment that engages in drive-in service or makes delivery of goods to customers in parking areas adjacent to the streets of the city shall see to it that the wrappings, containers and other papers which enclose or accompany such goods are not thrown or deposited or allowed to blow upon his premises and adjacent property and the streets of the city. If any wrapping, container, napkin, straw or other accompanying paper or trash shall accidentally flow or blow upon the adjacent property and the streets of the city, the owner, lessees and employees of such soda fountain, lunch counter, drugstore, grocery or other mercantile establishment engaging in drive-in service shall be jointly or severally responsible with the customers thereof for the immediate removal of the wrapping, container, napkin, straw, or accompanying paper or trash from the street. 
(Code 1956, § 11-11.2) 
Sec. 20-8. - Cleanliness or orderliness at container site. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in possession, charge or control of any premises to allow or permit garbage or trash container to be open or uncovered, and it shall be unlawful for any such person to permit or allow an accumulation of garbage, trash, or litter in the vicinity of any garbage or trash container serving such premises. 
(Ord. No. 1658, § 5, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-9. - Garbage, trash, etc., from businesses not to be placed in city receptacles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating any place of business in the city or for any employee, servant or agent of any such person to place or deposit garbage, trash, paper, rubbish or other waste material in any trash basket or waste receptacle maintained by the city upon a public street or sidewalk, when such garbage, trash, paper, rubbish or waste material accumulated in or came from such place of business. 
(Ord. No. 1658, § 6, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-10. - Garbage cart collection for disabled persons. 
    Any person who is a full-time resident of a residential unit who is disabled to the extent of being incapable of moving refuse and who obtains a physician's certificate as to this disability shall not be required to place the cart at curbside. This section shall not apply unless all of the persons in a residential unit are disabled and obtain a physician's certificate. These certificates shall be mailed to the director of solid waste for appropriate notification of pickup crews. 
(Ord. No. 1658, § 7, 9-3-96) 
Secs. 20-11-20-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal solid waste disposal authorized, Code of Ala., § 22-27-3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-21. - Established. 
    There is established in the city on and along all all-weather public streets a periodic refuse collection, hauling, and disposal service to be operated by, or under the supervision of, the solid waste department. The charges established in division 2 are based on such periodic collection, hauling and disposal service. 
(Code 1956, § 11-4(a); Ord. No. 1450, § 1, 10-20-92) 
Sec. 20-22. - Subscription required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in possession, charge or control, jointly or severally, of any premises where refuse is created or accumulated, and in the case of multiple dwellings or multiple occupancy which requires a city business license, for the owner or agent, jointly or severally, of the premises, to fail to subscribe to refuse service as created and at the charges established hereunder. 
(Code 1956, § 11-4(d)) 
Cross reference- Business license, § 12-16. 
Sec. 20-23. - Frequency of service. 
    Residential garbage collection shall occur on a once per week basis. Trash, originating on the premises, and recyclable materials which are placed in front of the owner's or occupant's premises but behind the curb and within three (3) feet thereof, shall be removed once per week in residential areas, except as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1956, § 11-4(b); Ord. No. 1450, § 2, 10-20-92) 
Sec. 20-24. - Placement of containers. 
(a)  Business establishments. All garbage containers and carts to be emptied under the supervision of the solid waste department from business establishments shall be placed at places to be determined by the director of solid waste on the days and between the hours designated by the director. 
(b)  Residences. All garbage cans for the collection from residences by or under the supervision of the solid waste department shall be placed near the back entrance of such residences in plain view, on the day designated by the director of solid waste unless alternative arrangements have been made by agreement with the director or residence is located in an area designated for cart service. 
(c)  Entry of buildings prohibited. No collection personnel are permitted to enter houses or buildings, garages or porches for collection of garbage. 
(Code 1956, § 11-8; Ord. No. 1450, § 3, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 1658, § 9, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-25. - Access to garbage containers. 
    It shall be incumbent upon tenants, lessees, occupants or owners of the premises to provide a safe and convenient entrance to and through the premises for the purpose of collecting garbage. All vicious animals shall either be confined or garbage containers placed at a point where collectors may empty same without attack from such animals. Where collections are made from private alleys and access ways, such approaches shall be maintained in such a manner as not to be a hazard to sanitary personnel or equipment. 
(Code 1956, § 11-9; Ord. No. 1658, § 10, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-26. - Procedures for providing, handling and management of garbage carts. 
(a)  Garbage carts for cart service pickup will be provided by the city to persons living in areas designated by the city for cart service. 
(b)  As to those carts which are purchased by the city, owned by the city, and issued to each garbage customer, the following regulations shall apply: 
(1)  On scheduled garbage pickup day, the garbage customer will be required to place the cart at the curbside not later than 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  Carts at curbside when emptied should be removed from curbside and should not remain there overnight. No person shall place any cart out for collection on a date when no collection is scheduled. 
(3)  The garbage customer who negligently or intentionally causes damage to a garbage cart will be responsible for said repairs, or replacement if the cart cannot be repaired. The garbage customer will be billed the City's cost for replacement or repair. 
(4)  No cart which has not been authorized by the solid waste department shall be used by a garbage customer for use in collection. 
(5)  No cart shall be loaded with concrete, bricks, dirt, scrap metal, rock or other heavy waste material. In such cases the customer will be responsible for separating the garbage from the waste for proper pickup. 
(6)  If the garbage customer moves from one cart collection area to another within the city, the cart will be moved to the new area and the solid waste department notified of the new location. 
(7)  When service to any garbage customer is discontinued (and a move is not contemplated to a new cart collection area) the solid waste department will be notified of the discontinuation and the cart will be picked up. 
(Ord. No. 1658, § 11, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-27. - Oversized wastes. 
    The service provided under this division shall remove, on an occasional basis, oversized burnable and nonburnable wastes from residential premises, except as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1956, § 1-4(c); Ord. No. 1658, § 12, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-28. - Dead animals; removal. 
    Dead animals in the corporate limits of the city, and within the city's right-of-way, not in excess of fifty (50) pounds in weight will be picked up by the solid waste department other than from places of business making a business of treating, handling or disposing of animals, but in no event shall any person having a dead animal on the premises occupied or under the control of such person allow it to remain undisposed of for a period of longer than twelve (12) hours. In the event the dead animals must be disposed of on a day other than the regular designated collection day, the solid waste department shall be notified. All animals above fifty (50) pounds must be removed within twelve (12) hours by the owner. The reasonable costs of removal shall be borne by the owner of the animal or the owner of the premises upon which the animal is deceased. 
(Code 1956, § 4-3; Ord. No. 1658, § 13, 9-3-96) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 3; dead animals defined as refuse, § 20-1. 
Sec. 20-29. - Collection of building debris, dirt, stumps, tree trunks. 
(a)  Building debris such as scrap lumber, plaster, roofing, concrete, brickbats and sanding dust resulting from the construction, repair or remodeling of any building or appurtenances on private property, dirt, stumps, and tree trunks will not be removed by the solid waste department, but the owner shall cause this waste to be privately removed, excepting however one occasional tree trunk or tree stump placed at the collection point by the owner or occupant rather than by a contractor, providing the trunk or stump is of such a size that it may be handled by one man. 
(b)  The city shall not be responsible for the collecting and hauling of rubbish, trash, limbs, brush or other debris from private property preliminary to, during or subsequent to construction of new buildings of whatever type prior to occupancy. Such material shall be removed by the owner of the property or the contractor responsible for the accumulation of same. 
(Code 1956, §§ 11-6, 11-11.5; Ord. No. 1450, § 6, 10-20-92) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; depositing dirt, rock, concrete, etc., on street, § 21-3. 
Sec. 20-30. - Tree surgeons. 
    It shall be the responsibility of all tree surgeons doing work on private property to remove from premises all residue and rubbish resulting from such work. 
(Code 1956, § 11-11.6; Ord. No. 1658, § 14, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-31. - Dumping prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, or cause to be dumped, any garbage upon any property other than a sanitary landfill. 
(Code 1956, § 11-11.1) 
Sec. 20-32. - Residential trash collection policy. 
(a)  Time. Trash should be placed at curbside the evening before the designated pickup day, when possible. 
(b)  Separation. Trash should be separated into two (2) distinct piles: leaves, grass clippings, straw, tree limbs or other wood products in one, and metal and other debris in another. 
(c)  Prohibited actions. 
(1)  Placing trash on medians and on vacant or abandoned residential or commercial property. 
(2)  Placing commercial building material by the curb for pickup. 
(3)  Placing the debris from a lot clearing project at the curb for pickup. 
(4)  Placing treetops and limbs from commercial wood cutting projects at the curb for pickup. 
(5)  Blocking the sidewalk with trash. 
(6)  Blocking gutters, ditches or any portions of the city's drain system with trash. 
(7)  Putting trash in the street creating a traffic hazard. 
(8)  Creating a fire hazard with trash not eligible for city pickup. 
(9)  Placing trash around fire hydrants, sign posts, guy wires, power poles, over water meters, over masonry work or against fences or mail boxes. 
(10)  Placing trash under low hanging power lines, tv cables or low tree limbs. 
(11)  Placing hazardous waste such as tires, creosote treated materials, asbestos, petroleum products, paints or chemicals of any kind in a trash pile. 
(d)  Collection fees for residential trash (yard waste). 
(1)  Residential trash (yard waste) will be collected at no additional charge if the volume of such trash placed at the curbside is less than five (5) cubic yards (six (6) feet by six (6) feet by four (4) feet). In the event that residential trash placed at the curbside exceeds five (5) cubic yards, the city utility account for the residence shall be charged a special trash collection fee as follows: 
a.  For amounts exceeding five (5) cubic yards, but less than eleven (11) cubic yards ..... $50.00 
b.  For amounts exceeding eleven (11) cubic yards, but no more than twenty-two (22) cubic yards ..... $100.00 
(Ord. No. 1658, § 15, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 1953, § 13, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 2155, § 17, 9-23-03; Ord. No. 2967, § 1, 3-22-16) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1597, adopted Sept. 5, 1995, repealed § 20-32, which pertained to use of sanitary landfill and derived from Code 1956, § 11-11; subsequently a new section has been added to read as herein set out. 
Secs. 20-33-20-45. - Reserved.

Sec. 20-46. - Collection agent. 
    The water works board of the city is designated as the agent of the city for the collection of all garbage service fees. Additional solid waste fees may be collected by the city finance department if designated by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1056, § 2, 9-15-81; Ord. No. 1319, § 2, 6-6-89; Ord. No. 1658, § 16, 9-3-96) 
Cross reference- Water works board collection agent for water and sewer fees, § 19-151; water works franchise listed, App. A.

Sec. 20-48. - Charges within police jurisdiction. 
    Persons residing within the police jurisdiction of the city may apply for garbage service at one hundred ten (110) per cent of the rates set out in section 20-47. 
(Ord. No. 1056, § 1(D), 9-15-81) 
Sec. 20-49. - City C/D Landfill rates. 
(a)  Any person desiring to use the city's C/D landfill for the purpose of dumping or disposing of inert materials generated in the city shall first secure a permit to do so from the revenue office at city hall. The applicable permit charges or fees shall be set forth in the permit fee schedule in the following subsection, except that Auburn University and persons who have received specific authorization from the city manager or his designated representative may do so without cost. 
(b)  Permit fee schedule. The schedule of charges and fees is as follows: 
Pick-up truck ..... $ 7.50

(Ord. No. 1056, § 1(E), 9-15-81; Ord. No. 1597, § 2, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 1658, § 18, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 20-50. - Multiple occupancies or dwelling units. 
    In all cases of multiple dwellings and/or multiple occupancy which require a city business license, it shall be the duty of the owner or agent jointly or severally to pay said service charges to the city as provided in this division; failure to comply with this provision shall be prima facie evidence of violation of section 1-9 of the City Code and shall be good and sufficient cause to have said license revoked in addition to such penalties as provided hereafter. 
(Ord. No. 1056, § 1(F), 9-15-81; Ord. No. 1319, § 1(18D), 6-6-89; Ord. No. 1658, § 19, 9-3-96) 
Cross reference- Business license, § 12-16. 
Sec. 20-51. - When bills due. 
    All bills for service hereunder shall be due and payable monthly for service commencing with bills to be payable July 1, 2000, provided however: initial service begun after the fifteenth of the month, no charge; on or before the fifteenth of the month, full charge. All payments shall be made to the water works board of the city. For any bill not paid by the fifteenth of the month in which due, a penalty of five (5) per cent of the monthly fee shall be levied. When necessary for the city or its agent to have an inspector or collector call at a residence or business establishment to compel payment of garbage service fees due, an additional charge of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be levied. All penalties, interest, and charges levied under this section shall be due and payable immediately. 
(Ord. No. 1056, § 1(B), 9-15-81; Ord. No. 1319, § 1(18B), 6-6-89; Ord. No. 1928, § 1, 6-20-2000) 
Sec. 20-52. - No refunds. 
    There shall be no refunds. 
(Ord. No. 1056, § 1(C), 9-15-81; Ord. No. 1319, § 1(18C), 6-6-89) 
Sec. 20-53. - Past-due bills. 
    Any garbage service customer failing or refusing to pay his garbage service bill in full within twenty-five (25) days after the rendition thereof will be in violation of this division and shall be fined between fifty dollars ($50.00) and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each day the violation continues, and further may be denied service for the collection of refuse provided by the city. The city may institute legal action to recover unpaid accounts and fines. 
(Ord. No. 1056, § 3, 9-15-81; Ord. No. 1319, § 3, 6-6-89; Ord. No. 1355, § 1, 4-3-90) 
Cross reference- Sewer usage charges, § 19-151 et seq. 
Sec. 20-54. - Special contracts terminated; exception. 
    All contracts with the city concerning special garbage service charges are hereby terminated. However, this provision shall not affect the validity of the general services agreement with Auburn University. 
(Ord. No. 1056, § 4, 9-15-81) 
Secs. 20-55-20-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PRIVATE HAULERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Business licenses and regulations, generally, Ch. 12. 

Sec. 20-66. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to haul or dispose of solid waste as the same is defined in this chapter and to dump the same in any manner without obtaining the permit provided for in this article and without complying with all of the terms and conditions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1077, § 2, 4-20-82) 
Sec. 20-67. - When permit not required. 
    A permit shall not be required for the hauling of certain solid wastes under provisions of section 20-29. 
(Ord. No. 1077, § 3, 4-20-82) 
Sec. 20-68. - Conditions of permit. 
(a)  Any person who desires to be exempt from the mandatory garbage service and charges of the city as provided for by section 22-27-3(e) of the Code of Alabama, 1975, as amended, and to haul and dispose of his own solid waste shall first apply to the city manager or his designated agent for a permit. Such permit shall be issued only upon the person's complying with the following provisions: 
(1)  Such applicant shall submit a written plan to the city manager setting forth the method proposed to be used to haul and dispose of such solid waste. 
(2)  All hauling of solid waste must be in a vehicle determined by the city to be suitable for the hauling of solid waste and approved as a part of the written plan. 
(3)  Such plan must make adequate provisions, as determined by the city manager, for timely and proper hauling and disposing of all such solid waste in an approved sanitary landfill. 
(4)  Before any permit issued under this article may be renewed, the applicant must submit to the city manager written evidence that all solid waste hauled under the permit has been disposed of in accordance with the plans submitted to the city and has been disposed of in an approved sanitary landfill. 
(Ord. No. 1077, § 3, 4-20-82) 
Sec. 20-69. - Duration of permit. 
    The permit issued under this article shall be for a period of three (3) months. 
(Ord. No. 1077, § 3, 4-20-82) 
Sec. 20-70. - Revocation of permit. 
    Any permit holder who does not comply with the plan submitted to the city manager upon which his permit is based shall be subject to having his permit forthwith revoked by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1077, § 4, 4-20-82) 
Chapter 21 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing bond to cover excavations in streets, § 5-261; retailing from vehicles prohibited on certain streets, § 16-2; charitable solicitations within rights-of-way, § 16-3; house numbering and street names, § 17-36 et seq.; littering streets, § 20-4; riding bicycles on sidewalks in downtown business district, § 22-11. 
State Law reference- Municipal powers relative to streets, sidewalks, etc., Code of Ala., § 11-49-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Standard specifications for roads and bridges adopted. 
    Any streets or sidewalks constructed within the City of Auburn shall be designed and built in accordance with the standards and specifications set forth in the latest version of the City of Auburn Public Works Design and Construction Manual and the latest version of the City of Auburn Standard Specifications. The Auburn Public Works Design and Construction Manual as approved and adopted by the city council is hereby incorporated into this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 21-2. - Standards for accommodating utilities on highway rights-of-way adopted. 
    Any streets or roads constructed within the City of Auburn which have or will involve the expenditure of state or federal highway funds shall be designed and constructed in accordance with latest versions of the State of Alabama Department of Transportation standards and specifications. 
(Ord. No. 859, § 1, 12-17-74; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 21-3. - Depositing of dirt, rock, concrete and other similar substances on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited any dirt, earth, rock, clay, sand, debris, rubbish, concrete or asphalt or any residue therefrom, or any similar material upon any street of this city. This section shall not prohibit anyone performing public works in connection with the streets from placing necessary materials at such places as may be prescribed by his contract with the city. 
(Ord. No. 413, § 1, 9-17-89; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Cross reference- Collection of building debris, § 20-29. 
Sec. 21-4. - Truck weight limits and restrictions. 
(a)  State provisions adopted. Section 32-9-20 of the Code of Alabama (1975), as amended, entitled "Schedule of Restrictions," is hereby adopted and made a part of the Code of Auburn, establishing and setting limits for the weight of vehicles allowed on streets in the City of Auburn, Alabama. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code above or shall fail to comply therewith, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed and set forth in section 1-9 of the Code of Auburn. 
(Ord. No. 1689, §§ 1, 2, 4-1-97; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Secs. 21-5-21-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET CONSTRUCTION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Motor fuels tax proceeds to be used in part for street construction and improvements, § 12-136. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 21-16-21-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 21-26. - Construction permit, plans, etc. 
    No person shall lay or construct any street, road or alleyway on any street or avenue in the city without first making application to the City of Auburn Development Review Team, obtaining approval from the development review team, and obtaining the required permits. The development review team process and permitting process are specified in General Section of the Public Works Design and Construction Manual. 
(Code 1956, §§ 18-4-18-7, 18-8; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 21-27. - Construction by private persons; inspections. 
    Whenever any street, alley or other public way is constructed by private persons within the corporate limits of the city, with the design or intention of dedicating the same to the city, all such construction work shall be subject to continuous inspection by the city engineer and persons employed by him. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7.1; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Secs. 21-28-21-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 21-41. - Generally. 
    Engineering plans for all new streets or any modification or alteration to the existing streets shall be submitted to the development review team as required by the Public Works Design and Construction Manual. The general layout or design of such streets shall be in accordance with the manual. The minimum design standards set forth in the Public Works Design and Construction Manual shall be complied with for all new street work unless expressly authorized by the governing body. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Cross reference- Subdivision ordinance (not printed herein) not affected by adoption of Code, § 1-3. 
Sec. 21-42. - Use of state specifications. 
    Construction of subgrade, base, paving, curbs, and gutters, drainage structures, etc., shall be in accordance with the publication adopted in section 21-1 of this Code. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(K)) 
Sec. 21-43. - City engineer's authority. 
    Any item not expressly covered by this division shall be subject to the decision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(M); Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 21-44. - Right-of-way and survey markers and monuments. 
    Right-of-way will be clearly indicated on the plans and corners, particularly at street intersections or at changes in widths of right-of-way, shall be clearly and permanently marked by an iron pin driven flush with the ground. In no case shall these markers be altered or destroyed without the prior approval of the city engineer. Any disturbance of federal, state or city survey monuments is expressly prohibited. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(E)) 
Sec. 21-45. - Subgrade. 
    All roads that are not to be paved under the same contract of all subgrades prepared prior to paving shall be graded uniformly so as to provide adequate drainage of storm water away from the roadbed. This shall imply that all ditches shall be graded to effectively drain all water away from the roadbed. All roadbeds shall be crowned to prevent storm water from running across the roadbed, except when approved by the city engineer. Subgrades shall be prepared in accordance with the publication adopted in section 21-1 of this Code. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(J)) 
Cross reference- Drainage, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 21-46. - Paving. 
    The minimum acceptable paving surface shall be considered to be a bituminous concrete wering surface consisting of two hundred (200) pounds per square yard of plant-mix type 416 laid on a primed six-inch compacted crushed stone base. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(G)) 
Sec. 21-47. - Widths. 
(a)  Street and alley widths for right-of-way shall be as follows: 
(1)  Major streets: Eighty (80) feet. 
(2)  Collector streets: Sixty (60) feet. 
(3)  Minor streets: Fifty (50) feet. 
(4)  Alleys: Twenty (20) feet. 
(b)  Minimum pavement widths of roadways and alleyways, excluding curb and gutter, line shall be as follows: 
(1)  Major streets: Forty-four (44) feet, except in business districts where the widths of paving will be established by the governing body. 
(2)  Collector streets: Thirty-three (33) feet. 
(3)  Minor streets: Twenty-seven (27) feet. 
(4)  Dead-end streets: Fifty (50) feet, with a turning circle having a minimum outside diameter of fifty (50) feet. 
(5)  Alleys: Sixteen (16) feet. 
(6)  Special cases: Due to limited right-of-way in certain built-up portions of the city, street widths may vary from these regulations if such widths are approved by the governing body. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(A), (F)) 
Sec. 21-48. - Grades and curves. 
(a)  Grades and vertical curves. 
(1)  Maximum grade shall be as follows: 
a.  Major streets: Six (6) per cent. 
b.  Collector streets: Ten (10) per cent. 
c.  Minor streets and alleys: Four (4) per cent. 
(2)  Minimum grades shall be not less than five-tenths per cent. 
(3)  All changes in street grades shall be connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equivalent to that distance necessary to maintain a safe sight distance. 
(b)  Alignment and visibility. 
(1)  Minimum radii of curvature shall be as follows: 
a.  Major streets: Four hundred (400) feet. 
b.  Collector streets: Three hundred (300) feet. 
c.  Minor streets: Three hundred (300) feet. 
d.  Alleys: Fifty (50) feet. 
(2)  A tangent of one hundred (100) feet between reversed curves is desirable. 
(3)  Clear visibility measured along the center line shall be provided for at least four hundred (400) feet on major streets, two hundred (200) feet on secondary streets, and at least one hundred (100) feet on minor streets. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(B), (C)) 
Sec. 21-49. - Intersections. 
(a)  Submission of a grading plan showing existing and proposed contour lines at one-foot intervals and a detailed design at unusual intersections may be required by the city engineer. 
(b)  Acute angles at street intersections are to be avoided and in no case will an angle of less than thirty (30) degrees be permitted. 
(c)  Street curb intersections shall be rounded by a radii of not less than twenty (20) feet. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(D)) 
Sec. 21-50. - Curbs and gutters. 
    Curbs and gutters shall be of monolithic construction, of integral concrete, the curbs to be six (6) inches high and the gutters at least eighteen (18) inches wide. Curb sections shall be no longer than ten (10) feet, with suitable expansion joint material provided at every fifth joint. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(H)) 
Sec. 21-51. - Drainage structures. 
    Culverts, drop inlets, etc., shall be provided as necessary to direct the flow of water away from or off the pavement surface. Location of such structures, length, dimensions, etc., shall be approved by the city engineer. In no case shall drainage structures, culverts, ditches, or any natural drainageway be obstructed or altered without prior approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(I)) 
Cross reference- Drainage, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 21-52. - Walkways. 
(a)  The portion of the street along the curb, or edge of the pavement or roadway shall be graded in a manner to provide proper drainage to the street and gutters and streets and to provide a safe walkway along and parallel to the street. The width of this strip of land may vary due to the width of the right-of-way and the width of the roadway, but shall be a minimum of six (6) feet if the distance between the curb line and property line will permit. 
(b)  In some cases it will be necessary to fill in this area and in other instances it will be necessary to cut and remove surplus excavation. The strip of land shall be graded on a maximum slope of one and one-half (11/2) feet horizontal to one foot vertical in both cut and fill sections. 
(c)  If it can be shown that there are extraordinary hardships brought about by complete compliance with these regulations due to extraordinary topographic conditions, the city engineer shall have the power to vary these regulations. 
(Code 1956, § 18-7(L)) 
Secs. 21-53-21-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALK, CURB, ETC., CONSTRUCTION, REPAIR, ETC. 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-66. - Construction permit. 
    No person shall lay or construct any sidewalk, curb or gutter on any street or avenue in the city without first making application to the City of Auburn Development Review Team, obtaining approval from the development review team, and obtaining the required permits. The development review team and permitting processes are specified in the General Section of the Public Works Design and Construction Manual. 
(Code 1956, §§ 18-1-18-3; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Secs. 21-67-21-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REPAIR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to require sidewalk repair, Code of Ala., § 11-49-2. 

Sec. 21-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Damage to a section of sidewalk and/or curb and gutter shall include, but not be limited to, cracks, breaks, chips, settlements or any appreciable movements of such section. 
    Section of sidewalk and/or curb and gutter shall mean that portion of the sidewalk and/or curb and gutter, including driveway curb cuts, between expansion joints, groove joints, edges of concrete or other dividing lines where a clean and neat abutment can be made between the new sidewalk and/or curb and gutter and the existing structures or ground lines. 
(Ord. No. 984, § 1, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 21-92. - Replacement required. 
    Any person who damages any section of sidewalk and/or curb and gutter within the rights-of-way of the city, shall replace the same in its entirety and shall restore the same to its original, or better condition, in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the city engineer and to the satisfaction of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 984, § 2, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 21-93. - Prior submittal of plans. 
    Prior to the commencement of repairs or restoration of damaged sidewalks and/or curb and gutter, the person proposing to make the repair shall notify the city engineer and obtain a permit for such work. In addition, such person shall notify the city engineer at the conclusion of the work so an inspection of the work can be made by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 984, § 3, 6-19-79) 
Sec. 21-94. - Notice of violation. 
    Any person who damages any section of a public sidewalk and/or curb and gutter and who does not replace or repair the same as required by section 21-92 shall be served by the city engineer with written notice of his violation of this division. If after receipt of the written notice the person does not comply with section 21-92, the city engineer shall cause the person to be served with a citation requiring him to appear before the municipal judge. 
(Ord. No. 984, § 4, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 21-95. - Penalties. 
    Any person who, after being served with the written notice described in section 21-94, shall not repair the damage as required by section 21-92 shall be guilty of an offense against the city and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of this Code, plus the cost of repairing the damage. 
(Ord. No. 984, § 5, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2743, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Secs. 21-96-21-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 22. 

Sec. 21-111. - Definition of "parade." 
    As used in this article the term "parade" shall mean any parade, march or procession upon any street. 
Sec. 21-112. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
Sec. 21-113. - Permit required. 
    No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, without a parade permit issued by the chief of police. 
(Code 1956, § 19-9) 
Sec. 21-114. - Permit applications. 
(a)  A person desiring a parade permit shall file an application with the city clerk on forms provided by such officer. Such application shall be filed not less than seven (7) days nor more than sixty (60) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(b)  The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade; 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct; 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted; 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals, and description of the vehicles; 
(7)  The hours when such parade will start and terminate; 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade; 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas; 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade; 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the clerk a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf; 
(13)  Any additional information which the chief of police or clerk shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(c)  The chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, may consider any application hereunder which is filed less than seven (7) days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
Sec. 21-115. - Standards for permit issuance. 
    The chief of police shall issue a parade permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of this city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to this city; 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of this city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire; 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; 
(8)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, cause, goods or events and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
Sec. 21-116. - Notice of permit denial. 
    If the chief of police disapproves the application for a parade permit, the city clerk shall mail to the applicant within three (3) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of such action. 
Sec. 21-117. - Alternative permit. 
    The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade permit, may authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five (5) days after notice of such action, file a written notice of acceptance with the city clerk. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
Sec. 21-118. - Contents of permit. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time; 
(2)  Minimum speed; 
(3)  Maximum speed; 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; 
(7)  Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1956, § 19-9) 
Sec. 21-119. - Carrying permit. 
    The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
Sec. 21-120. - Revocation of permit. 
    The chief of police may, after a hearing affording due process, revoke a parade permit issued hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. 
Sec. 21-121. - Compliance with laws and regulations. 
    A person holding a parade permit shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
Chapter 22 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Motor fuels tax proceeds to be used in part for installation of traffic-control devices, § 12-136; speed of trains, § 13-8; reflection materials for joggers, bicyclists, § 13-11; junked motor vehicles, § 15-36; parades, § 21-111 et seq.; vehicles for hire, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Alabama Rules of the Road Act, Code of Ala., § 32-5A-1 et seq.; general powers of local authorities, Code of Ala., § 32-5-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2744, § 1, adopted Jan. 17, 2012, amended Art. I to read as herein set out. Former Art. I, § 22-1-22-25, pertained to similar subject matter. For a complete history of former Art. I see the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    The definitions contained in Code of Ala., § 32-1-1.1, as amended, shall be applicable to this chapter. In addition, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Campus shall mean land lying within the corporate limits of the city and owned or leased by the college. 
    College shall mean Auburn University. 
    Motor truck shall mean any motor-propelled vehicle designed for carrying freight or merchandise and not operated or driven on fixed rails or tracks; but it shall not include self-propelled vehicles designed primarily for passenger transportation, but equipped with frames, racks or bodies having a load capacity not exceeding one thousand (1,000) pounds. 
    Parking meter shall mean any mechanical device or meter not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected for the regulation of parking by authority of this chapter. Each parking meter installed shall indicate by proper legend the legal parking time established by the city and when operated at all times indicate the balance of legal parking time, and at the expiration of such period shall indicate illegal or overtime parking. 
    Parking meter space shall mean any space within a parking meter zone, adjacent to a parking meter and which is duly designated for the parking of a single vehicle by lines painted or otherwise durably marked on the curb or on the surface of the street adjacent to or adjoining the parking meters. 
    Parking meter zone shall mean any restricted street or portion of a street, upon which parking meters are located. 
    Through truck traffic shall mean the passing from a point outside the city, through the city, to another point, other than the point of origin outside the city, of motor trucks, pole trailers, semitrailers, trailers, and truck tractors or any one of them or combination of any two (2) or more of them. 
(Ord. No. 2744, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-2. - Manual for traffic-control devices. 
    The manual and specifications for traffic-control devices adopted by the state pursuant to Code of Ala., § 32-5A-30 are hereby adopted as if set out in full in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2744, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 22-3. - Traffic-control signs, signals, etc., ratified. 
    The location and existence of all traffic-control signs, signals, devices and markings which are in place on the adoption date of this Code are hereby ratified and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 2744, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Cross reference- Certain types of ordinances saved from repeal, § 1-3. 
Sec. 22-4. - Installation and maintenance of traffic-control signs, signals, etc. 
    The city engineer shall install and maintain such traffic-control signs, signals, devices and markings as are required by law or ordinance; however, the authority to mark off traffic lanes and parking places on roadways situated within the boundaries of the campus of the college shall be exercised only in cooperation with the president of the college and his successors in office. 
(Ord. No. 2744, § 1, 1-17-12) 
State Law reference- Authority to place and maintain traffic control signs, signals, etc., Code of Ala., § 32-5-1, 32-5-31. 
Sec. 22-5. - Placement of signs at intersections. 
    Suitable signs shall be placed at each intersection bearing the words "through street," "stop," "yield" or some similar warning signal. 
State Law reference- Authority to designate through highways and stop and yield intersections, Code of Ala., § 32-5A-113; vehicles entering stop or yield intersections, Code of Ala., § 32-5A-112. 
Sec. 22-6. - Directing traffic. 
(a)  For the purpose of assisting local law enforcement personnel with traffic control in the city and its police jurisdiction, the military police units and members thereof of the Alabama National Guard are authorized to perform the function of directing traffic on the public streets within the city and its police jurisdiction. 
(b)  The activity authorized in this section shall be performed upon the request of the chief of police and under the direction, control, and supervision of the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 2744, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Cross reference- Police department, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Obedience to persons authorized to direct traffic, Code of Ala., § 32-5A-4. 
Sec. 22-7. - Speed limits-Generally. 
(a)  Seventy (70) mph limits. No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than seventy (70) miles per hour in the following listed zones of the city: 
Interstate 85 from the west city limits northeasterly to the east city limits. 
(b)  Fifty-five (55) mph limits. No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than fifty-five (55) miles per hour in the following listed zones of the city: 
Martin Luther King Drive (Alabama Highway No. 14) from the west city limits easterly toward the city to the intersection of Willow Creek Road. 
North College Street (Alabama Highway No. 147) from the north city limits southerly toward the city to the intersection of East University Drive/Shug Jordan Parkway (SR 267). 
South College Street (Alabama Highway No. 147/U.S. 29) from the south city limits northerly toward the city to the bridge located approximately nine hundred and forty (940) feet south of Shell Toomer Parkway. 
Shug Jordan Parkway (State Route 267).

(Code 1956, § 19-20; Ord. No. 1181, § 1, 1-8-85; Ord. No. 1216, §§ 1-3, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 1236, §§ 1, 2, 11-18-86; Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 9-20-88; Ord. No. 1320, § 1, 6-6-89; Ord.
